subject: Eradicate eventlet and fix bug lp:959221
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-11 03:43:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/28862/1/check/gate-python-swiftclient-requirements/12 : SUCCESS in 00:00:04
- http://logs.openstack.org/28862/1/check/gate-python-swiftclient-pep8/275 : SUCCESS in 00:00:31
- http://docs-draft.openstack.org/28862/1/check/gate-python-swiftclient-docs/225/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 00:00:36
- http://logs.openstack.org/28862/1/check/gate-python-swiftclient-python26/273 : SUCCESS in 00:00:37
- http://logs.openstack.org/28862/1/check/gate-python-swiftclient-python27/273 : SUCCESS in 00:00:31
'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-05-12 23:58:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I think this makes a lot of sense. Back when swiftclient was part of swift, then it made some sense to have the explicit eventlet imports, but I don't think it does any more.

My understanding of Eventlet applications is that they pretty much have to use eventlet.patcher.monkey_patch(), so any application that's doing that is already getting Eventlet's hooks into socket.py and all its low-level friends, and therefore swiftclient can use the normal httplib stuff and still be Eventlet-compatible.

I was concerned about the SSL monkeypatching possibly being broken, but calling patcher.monkey_patch(socket=True) gets the ssl module as well, at least according to <http://eventlet.net/doc/basic_usage.html#eventlet.monkey_patch>."}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2013-05-13 09:08:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

we/I should have done this at the firt commit of the fork from main swift :)'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-13 09:08:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-11 03:43:10.000000000', 'message': "Eradicate eventlet and fix bug lp:959221

The bug is simple: whenever swift uploads to a Swift with SSL,
it uses 100% CPU. It happens because we use HTTPSConnection from
eventlet that loops like that, while holding the interpreter lock.

Now, it could be fixed in eventlet, but let's try something more
natural: drop the eventlet's HTTP client. We do not use green
threads in the client anymore, so it's not like we need it for that.

Note that in most cases clients do not use the BufferedHTTPConnection
either, because it's only installed on Swift server nodes, not on
workstations. Get rid of that too.

bug: 959221
Change-Id: I1eb932779d4171598b3efaa043f817b9c6c995c4
"}]
commit_message:
Eradicate eventlet and fix bug lp:959221

The bug is simple: whenever swift uploads to a Swift with SSL,
it uses 100% CPU. It happens because we use HTTPSConnection from
eventlet that loops like that, while holding the interpreter lock.

Now, it could be fixed in eventlet, but let's try something more
natural: drop the eventlet's HTTP client. We do not use green
threads in the client anymore, so it's not like we need it for that.

Note that in most cases clients do not use the BufferedHTTPConnection
either, because it's only installed on Swift server nodes, not on
workstations. Get rid of that too.

bug: 959221
Change-Id: I1eb932779d4171598b3efaa043f817b9c6c995c4

commit_message:
xenapi: disable the xenapi agent by default

fixes bug 1178223
DocImpact

Currently users get very confused when first trying out openstack
on XenAPI becuase the VM boot is hugely slowed down by waiting
for the guest agent.

We may move to deprecate the use of the agent this release,
and this is a good step in that direction too.

A later change will start to control the agent per image.

Change-Id: I7436b026e6672744537dbb6a4b767225f37e5883

Improve unit tests for python-quantumclient

Partially fixes bug 1137783. Add tests for:
quantumclient.common.utils

Partially Fixes: bug #1137783

subject: Add multi range support for segemented objects.
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-11 01:34:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Those both affect GET requests to many-segment manifests, and it's impossible to properly evaluate this change without those other changes being in place."}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2012-11-16 21:16:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-16 21:49:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-11-27 00:19:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Okay, the prerequisites have landed, so I've started to look at this one.

One problem this has is that it amplifies requests unnecessarily. Consider a manifest with 100-byte segments. A request with "Range: bytes=0-9,100-109,200-209" will get the first 10 bytes of the first 3 segments, and so there must be a total of 4 requests made to the object server (one to find the manifest, then three for the segments). 

Further, a request with "Range: bytes=0-9,20-29,40-49,60-69,100-109,130-139" only hits 2 segments, and so it should only make a total of 3 requests to the object server (manifest + 2 segments). However, with this patch, a total of 7 object-server requests are made: one for the manifest, and one for each range. I'd like to see ranges batched up. In the above example, that means:

 * one request for the manifest
 * one request for the first segment w/bytes=0-9,20-29,40-49,60-69
 * one request for the second segment with bytes=0-9,30-39

Second problem: the Range header is ignored completely for objects with many segments, i.e. >= CONTAINER_LISTING_LIMIT. In one test, I used a 100-byte object with segments of size 10 and CONTAINER_LISTING_LIMIT set to 4. Even headers that only referenced the first segment (e.g. bytes=0-4) resulted in a response with status 200 and the whole object in the response. Is this an intentional decision to ignore Range headers for many-segmented objects?'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-01-09 06:03:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button  under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-01-09 06:03:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-02-07 05:29:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

I haven't looked at the code in detail, but I exercised the multi-range support with a segmented file in my SAIO a good bit, and it looks great so far."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-02-07 07:30:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

I haven't had time to really investigate this (sorry!), but I do have a couple of questions: 

First, what happens with a multi-range request against a segmented object with more than swift.common.constraints.CONTAINER_LISTING_LIMIT segments? 

Second, is this patch set now coalescing requests to backend servers? That is, if I have an object segmented into 100-byte pieces and I ask for "Range: bytes=0-9,20-29,40-49,100-109,120-129,150-159", how many requests are made to object servers? The optimal answer is two: one for bytes 0-9,20-29,40-49 of the first segment and one for bytes 0-9,20-29,50-59 of the second segment. What's this patch do?

Apologies if the answer is obvious from the code.'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-02-07 17:31:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

@Sam, I started out testing w/your previous problems with the patch.  The requests to the back-end object server(s) are now optimal (confirmed with tcpdump -X on my SAIO).

The ranges get sorted and multi-range requests get passed to each segment as necessary.'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-02-07 17:32:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

@Sam, I did not look at CONTAINER_LISTING_LIMIT  behavior at all, though.'}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2013-02-08 18:28:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Sam, Darrell,
   When number of the segments is greater than the
CONTAINER_LISTING_LIMIT, only the first page of the
segments is used as if the segments on the reset of
the pages do not exist. This is the behavior that
we talked during one of the online meetings.'}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2013-02-08 18:32:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Sam, Darrell,
   I've also re-engineered some of the segmentedIterable code.
Now multiple ranges within one segment passed to object server
within one request, content streamed back to proxy and
eventually assembled together. Because of some of the boundary
issues, there is an extra http header created to pass to
object server to indicate what boundary strings, last range
and if the closing boundary should be rendered etc. It is
more complicated than I thought."}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-02-13 06:55:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: (1 inline comment)

I still haven't had time for a substantive code review, but there is one minor tactical suggestion inline."}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2013-02-15 15:20:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Darrell, using that method will be better in what sense?
By looking at the code how itemgetter is implemented, it
seems to me that the lambda is more efficient. I could
very well miss something here.'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2013-02-22 17:30:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Darrell's been on an optimization kick lately:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/19712/
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/19605/

I think this is all he ment:

    clayg:~$ python -m timeit -s 'from operator import itemgetter' 'sorted(((i, i) for i in range(100)), key=itemgetter(0))'
    10000 loops, best of 3: 24.6 usec per loop
    clayg:~$ python -m timeit 'sorted(((i, i) for i in range(100)), key=lambda x: x[0])'
    10000 loops, best of 3: 31.9 usec per loop"}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-02-22 19:45:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Oh, I hadn't even benchmarked the two, though the result is interesting.

My suggestion was purely stylistic.  I guess I just have a preference for operator.{itemgetter,attrgetter} over lambdas which do the equivalent.  I think it reads better.

If you don't want to change it, it's fine."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-02-25 20:05:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(3 inline comments)

There's a few things in inline comments. If I've misunderstood anything, please correct me.

'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-03-21 23:41:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Tested it with curl and it seems to work okay.

My one problem is with what SegmentedIterable.set_segment_content_type_and_length() does; it reads the entire listing iterator to determine if a given set of ranges is satisfiable or not.

I don't think that the proxy should do this. Let me put my security hat on for a second:

<security-hat src="http://ledchristmaslighting.com/images/64165_black_and_white_top_hat.jpg">

Imagine that Mallory has a grudge against Example Company X, and Example Company X runs a public Swift cluster called XFiles.

Mallory takes out his credit card, signs up for an XFiles account, and proceeds to create 100 million 1-byte files in a container called "tinyfiles". This takes weeks, but Mallory is patient.

Mallory then creates a manifest named "dos/manifest" with "X-Object-Manifest: tinyfiles/".

The stage is now set.

Next, Mallory makes a single request with curl:

    $ curl -H "X-Auth-Token: AUTH_blahblah" -H "Range: bytes=0-0, 99999999-99999999" https://xfiles.example.com/v1.0/AUTH_mallory/dos/manifest

This manifest references 10^8 files, and the default container listing limit is 10^4, so the proxy will end up performing 10^4 container listing requests to determine if the ranges are satisfiable.

That's a pretty darn big amplification factor. Mallory makes one single request, and XFiles's proxies have to make 10,000 backend requests. If Mallory launches a few hundred concurrent requests, XFiles's proxies are going to become really overloaded and slow way down, perhaps even becoming unusable by other clients.

</security-hat>

That's just how I see it, though. It's possible that others will disagree, in which case I invite them to (please!) chime in here.'}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2013-03-22 15:14:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

Sam, SegmentedIterable.set_segment_content_type_and_length()
method go through the passed in iterator and does not actually
send a single request. The iterator is already available. Are
you saying that read each iterator causes a read request back
to the object server from proxy server? I am not seeing that
happening in my environment. Can you confirm that is really
the case? If it is, how to recreate this behavior. BTW, that
method only get called when it is a segmented object and the
suggestion was taken from a previous reviewer.'}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2013-03-22 15:32:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Rebased'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-03-22 15:32:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-03-22 18:04:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

To see this actually happen, put this in your swift.conf:

    [swift-constraints]
    container_listing_limit = 4

Then restart everything and do an object GET for an object with a lot of segments (say, 10 or more).

In your Swift logs, you'll see a whole bunch of container-server GETs with the same transaction ID. Those are the proxy server fetching the pages of the container listing.


Code-wise, you can see it in the proxy's object controller. The SegmentedIterable gets fed a variable called 'listing', which is the result of depaginating 'pages_iter', which itself comes out of _listing_pages_iter(). That method returns a generator that performs requests to the container servers and yields each page lazily.

By consuming all of the listing iter at once, that laziness is defeated, opening the door for a DoS attack.

You may also find it helpful to look at commit 83bbd0a in which that laziness was fixed after being broken for a while."}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2013-03-25 00:19:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Rebased'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-03-25 00:20:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-03-25 21:12:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Closer, but not quite there yet.

The way this handles range requests that fall within the first $LIMIT segments is correct. However, the way it handles range requests that fall outside the first $LIMIT segments is incorrect.

The problem is that the user will get back a 416 for range requests that fall outside the first $LIMIT segments, and that's not necessarily correct.

Here's an example to help illustrate:

Assume:

* CONTAINER_LISTING_LIMIT is set to 10
* an object has 20 segments of 1,000 bytes each (total size 20 KB)

The user makes a GET request with "Range: bytes=11000-11999". The proxy performs one container GET, retrieves 10 object listings with size 1000 bytes each, notices that 11000 > 10000, and returns a 416 response.

Next, the user makes a GET request without a range header for the same object and gets back 20,000 bytes.

These two different responses are contradictory; Swift can't say that 11000-11999 is an unsatisfiable range and then return 20,000 bytes.

The correct thing to do here (and it sucks for the user, but it's all we've got) is to return a 200 and send the full object. (RFC2616 section 14.35.2: "A server MAY ignore the Range header.")

So, to clarify: in the case where a range request wants any byterange that falls outside of the first $CONTAINER_LISTING_LIMIT segments, Swift should respond with a 200 and send the entire object.'}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2013-03-26 01:24:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

Sam, think about this case, range:bytes=1-1, 11000-11900,
what behavior should it be?'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-03-26 16:25:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

That response would have to be a 200 as well.

To see why, consider another object with a whole lot of 1000-byte segments, and a request for bytes=1-1, 11000000-11000900.

If Swift were to check that range, then we're open to that same DoS attack.

An even easier case is bytes=0-0,-1  (first and last bytes). To even figure out what the last byte is requires the proxy server to perform the full container listing.

It seems to me that any byterange falling outside of the first $CONTAINER_LISTING_LIMIT segments forces Swift to return a 200 response."}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2013-03-26 17:31:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

Sam, actually for that case, it should have only returned 
the first range with status code 206. This is the case that
we have discussed long ago when we first added the multi-range
support. For ranged request, the ranges may contain some valid
some invalid ranges. If there is a range like 10-7, then 416
will be returned. If there is a range like 1000-1001 (assume
the file is less than 1000 bytes long), then that range can
not be satisfied. that also produces a 416. But if that range
is mixed with a valid range, then only 206 is returned. So the
current behavior is consistent with what we have already
implemented for non-segmented object. You were saying about
the ranged and non ranged request not being consistent, I
think that is actually correct. but since the requests are
different, the behavior should be also different.'}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2013-03-26 17:35:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

Sam, for this case
"An even easier case is bytes=0-0,-1 (first and last bytes). To even figure out what the last byte is requires the proxy server to perform the full container listing"

The current implementation will return the first byte and
the last byte of the last segment on the first page. The
request to the container server is only once.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-03-26 17:49:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

Right, but Swift can't lie to the user.

Let's go back to considering the 20000 byte object with 20x 1000-byte segments, like before.

Say the user wants bytes=0-31,-32 (the first and last 32 bytes). If Swift returns the first 32 bytes of segment 1 and the last 32 bytes of segment 10, then the response has the wrong bytes in it! The last 32 bytes of segment 10 are not the last 32 bytes in the object.

Since Swift can't interpret the range relative to just the first page (wrong bytes in response), can't fetch more pages (DoS attack), and can't send a 416 (ranges might actually be satisfiable; we don't know), the only option left is to send a 200."}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2013-03-26 18:07:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

How do we know that range:byte=1-1, -1 can not be satisfied
without knowing the total length?'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-03-26 18:34:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

We don't. We either know that the byterange *is* satisfiable, or that it *may be* satisfiable.

When we've got fewer than $CONTAINER_LISTING_LIMIT segments, then we have a nice predicate: a byterange is either satisfiable or not. We can say 206 or 416 as appropriate.

When we've got more than $CONTAINER_LISTING_LIMIT segments, then we don't have that nice predicate any more. Given a byterange, all we know is that either (a) it uses some bytes from the first page of segments, so it is satisfiable, or (b) it does not use any bytes from the first page of segments, so we don't know if it's satisfiable or not.

It's a crappy place to be in. HTTP sort of assumes that you know how long (in bytes) a resource is. If you look at RFC 2616 section 14.35.1, it says that a 416 is returned when no byteranges are satisfiable, and otherwise a 206 is returned containing all satisfiable byteranges. It doesn't say anything about byteranges that *may be* satisfiable. So, if we have any maybe-satisfiable byteranges to deal with, the only thing we can do according to the RFC is to ignore the Range header entirely and return a 200."}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2013-03-26 19:13:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

Sam, not sure how to handle in this case. for a segmented
object, a request like this range:bytes=1-1, -1 may be 206
and may be 200 (if we do what you asked), but there is no
way of knowing in advance. I was thinking that when you 
actually return the entire object, that does not reduce the
number of visits to container server since proxy server has
to know where each segment is by asking container, why will that be any better than what it is doing now?
I am also thinking about extending the HEAD operation which
returns the content type and total length by query the container db for segmented objects. Currently it returns
content length 0 for segmented object.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-03-27 01:59:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

That's what I'm saying: if we don't know from the first page of the container listing, then return a 200.

So, for the case you mentioned (bytes=1-1,-1), if there were over $CONTAINER_LISTING_LIMIT segments, we'd return a 200, and if there were fewer, a 206.

The reason returning a 200 is better than doing the full listing up-front is that the 200 response lazily reads the container as needed, so if the client stops accepting bytes, the proxy stops doing work. If the proxy does the listing up-front, then the client doesn't have to do any work at all to keep the proxy busy.

It's the ratio of client work to server work that's important. An up-front listing uses a very small amount of client work (send request w/Range header) to produce a very large amount of server work (huge numbers of container GET requests). Lazy listing balances the two out; the server does one container GET, then starts doing object GETs and streaming the bytes out. If the client doesn't use its resources to consume those bytes, the server stops doing any work."}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2013-03-29 14:45:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

Sam, that change can be very simple, I can simply remove the range header when that happens. that will basically turn the
ranged request into a non-ranged request. Do you think that
is an acceptable solution? Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-04-01 19:39:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

Sure, seems like it ought to work.'}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2013-04-08 14:53:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-04-08 15:33:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-04-24 21:00:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

Some notes:

There needs to be more validation in swob.SegmentBoundary(). I can pass in a string that doesn't meet all the requirements, say "X-Segment-Boundary: blahblahfishcakes; status=0" and SegmentBoundary doesn't care. If any of those required fields are missing, then it should raise ValueError.

I'm not a fan of the name "status" in SegmentBoundary, either, nor the magic numbers 0 and 1. If you're using 0 and 1 to encode a boolean value, that's fine. Just rename the property from "status" to something that names what it really is. From a look at the code, perhaps "use_multipart_byteranges" would be a better name. And like I said, it looks boolean; if it is, then use of 0 and 1 is just fine. There's no need to parse "True" and "False" or any such baloney.

Also, if I deliberately break the last_range_ending parsing like so:

    #self.last_range_ending = int(param_v)
    self.last_range_ending = 0  # intentionally broken to check for test coverage

then there's some tests that break (hooray!), but they break in such a way that one doesn't even get any headers back from the proxy. This is bad; one should at least get back a 500. I narrowed it down to test.unit.proxy.test_server.TestObjectController.test_ranged_req_segments_container_listing_limit; it looks like the very last readuntil2crlfs() call is getting no data whatsoever. I haven't had time to track that down, but there's some code somewhere that needs to be made more robust.

I'm likely to have more feedback as I get deeper into this changeset, but that probably won't be today.'}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2013-04-26 14:57:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17:

Sam, I will address your comments when they are all in. Thanks for reviewing the patch.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-04 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-04 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17:

commit_message:
Add multi range support for segemented objects.

With this implementation, swift can now support requests using
multiple ranges such as Range:bytes=1-3, 5-10, 20-50 against both
single and segmented objects. This patch completes the multi range
support blueprint.

Change-Id: I7481ac89ae864163d3c4967cad20c34ea84799bf

commit_message:
Set default values for NFS/GlusterFS share_config files

By default, set:
 nfs_shares_config = /etc/cinder/nfs_shares
 glusterfs_shares_config = /etc/cinder/glusterfs_shares

This makes use of these drivers require one less manual
configuration step.

Also fix wording of help for glusterfs/nfs_mount_point_base
options.

Change-Id: I93bd3a8f08d4d5307f78e983d1080afae663dfe4

subject: Deprecate tools/nova_create_flavors.sh
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-07 05:00:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/28381/1/check/gate-heat-pep8/2852 : SUCCESS in 00:01:14
- http://logs.openstack.org/28381/1/check/gate-heat-python26/2807 : SUCCESS in 00:02:11
- http://logs.openstack.org/28381/1/check/gate-heat-python26-centos6/75 : SUCCESS in 00:01:47 (non-voting)
- http://logs.openstack.org/28381/1/check/gate-heat-python27/2806 : SUCCESS in 00:01:28
- http://logs.openstack.org/28381/1/check/dev-heat-coverage/1299 : SUCCESS in 00:02:41 (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2013-05-07 07:54:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Why are we doing this?  It's just a developer convenience tool, users are under no obligation to use it - if you want tools/openstack to default to not creating these flavors then just remove the call to nova_create_flavors.sh in that script, I don't see the point in blowing away a script which some of us find useful.

If we really must do this, then we need to align all of the example templates (in heat-templates) InstanceType parameter Default and AllowedValues to those which nova provides by default."}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2013-05-07 22:06:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Why are we doing this? It's just a developer convenience tool, users are under no obligation to use it - if you want tools/openstack to default to not creating these flavors then just remove the call to nova_create_flavors.sh in that script, I don't see the point in blowing away a script which some of us find useful.

There are a few reasons which I think add up to this being worth it:
- This script is only required because the example templates assume a first generation AWS flavor list. https://review.openstack.org/#/c/28379/ addresses that.
- Heat will soon be enabled by default for all OpenStack gating. Currently nova_create_flavors.sh gets called by devstack. Calling this for every tempest run has 2 problems:
  1. It is slow to run, adding precious seconds to gating
  2. Changing the flavors might affect other tempest checks
- Heat might be evaluated against existing openstack installations, and it would be nice if they could use the example templates without having to modify them or replace all their flavors 

> If we really must do this, then we need to align all of the example templates (in heat-templates) InstanceType parameter Default and AllowedValues to those which nova provides by default.

(I know you've found this, but for those who haven't https://review.openstack.org/#/c/28379/ )

Another option is to add a conditional in devstack to continue running nova_create_flavors.sh by default but not for tempest runs, but I think overall it would be better to go the whole hog."}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2013-05-07 22:32:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Ok, I'm not super-convinced by the other arguments, but the tempest gate speed issue is a compelling reason to drop this, as I know it's slow, particularly when nova rate limiting makes the kludgy retry logic kick in."}, {'account_id': 4715, 'date': '2013-05-13 04:50:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-13 04:50:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

Starting gate jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-13 04:52:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/28381/1/gate/gate-heat-python27/2893 : SUCCESS in 00:01:25
'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-13 04:52:28.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

instead.

[{'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2013-03-27 04:08:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2013-04-01 22:52:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2013-04-01 22:56:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Work In Progress

cleaning up'}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2013-04-01 23:09:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

Why check for the home directory alone?  Why look for 0700 specifically?  If the goal is to ensure that the destination can be used by httpd, it would probably make more sense to check the permissions in a generic way, since there is nothing stopping a user from choosing a path with different but still unusable permissions that is not under /home."}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2013-04-01 23:23:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

I only check for /home because (as per the comment) a couple of guides I found for Fedora did the installation in /home.  

I'm not sure a generic path checker has a lot of value for others, but the quick check for /home permissions will probably save some newbies (like myself) some time getting setup."}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2013-04-02 03:14:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2013-04-02 03:14:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

commit_message:
Basic check for homedir permissions

Several guides suggest using data directories under your homedir,
rather than the default /opt area.  This is fine, but on RHEL6 and
similar distros homedirs are very restrictive 0700 permissions which
doesn't allow things like httpd to pass through to serve up files.

Even though stack.sh is taking over the host, changing permissions
automatically is not a nice idea.  So we just warn when it looks like
this is happening.

Change-Id: I9cd70e7fe90638a2a5c3b8fd94756afacac7c7be

commit_message:
Make sure isolated tenants are not left behind.

The skip was being called after isloated creds were created. The manager is already
created by the base class.

Change-Id: I36fe83e665aab111f40db03cee52be0d7550d2d0

Declare the config attribute in a simpler way

tempest/test.py was declared in the __init__ in order to avoid possible style check issues.

Change-Id: I781c24d1b82d169a40aee6a264dbc203e5833f87

commit_message:
Add Aggregate XML client and tests.

Add Aggregate XML client for create, delete, get, list,
add_host, and remove_host.
This also adds tests using the client.

Partially Implements: blueprint missing-tempest-tests

Change-Id: Id0cb160e5dacc7acbc2ea091dd1160ee999d3887

[{'created': '2013-05-12 06:03:01.000000000', 'message': 'OVS cleanup utility removes veth pairs

Fixes bug 1094185

OVSInterfaceDriver plug() creates a veth pair and add it to an OVS
bridge when ovs_use_veth=True. It is useful that OVS cleanup utility
removes such veth paris in addition to removing OVS ports.

Veth pairs to be removed are veth devices corresponding to ports
removed when all_ovs_port==False. Veth pairs created to connect
the integration bridge and physical bridges are not removed.

commit_message:
OVS cleanup utility removes veth pairs

Fixes bug 1094185

OVSInterfaceDriver plug() creates a veth pair and add it to an OVS
bridge when ovs_use_veth=True. It is useful that OVS cleanup utility
removes such veth paris in addition to removing OVS ports.

Veth pairs to be removed are veth devices corresponding to ports
removed when all_ovs_port==False. Veth pairs created to connect
the integration bridge and physical bridges are not removed.

Change-Id: Ia87f0464e69a45dd0bdfd907ac71a003df9fc23f

For the most part, the dhcp agent uses the root_helper setting from the [AGENT]

commit_message:
in dhcp_agent, always use quantum.conf root_helper

Fixes bug #1178003.

For the most part, the dhcp agent uses the root_helper setting from the [AGENT]
section of /etc/quantum/quantum.conf. However, in a couple of spots, the
root_helper setting from the [DEFAULT] section of /etc/quantum/dhcp_agent.ini
was being used.

Change-Id: Id2f3140374a705cf7a0d2a784e4f321cc54f602e

[{'created': '2013-05-12 04:49:40.000000000', 'message': 'Create veth peer in namespace.

 * Update veth pair creation to set the namespace of the peer
   device on creation rather than subsequently adding it to the
   namespace.
 * This change supports kernels with limited namespace support
   (e.g. RHEL 6.5) so long as ovs_use_veth is set to True.
 * Addresses bug 1171727

Change-Id: I1885acc9934e7627bb9872703df7f5edf2980722

commit_message:
Create veth peer in namespace.

 * Update veth pair creation to set the namespace of the peer
   device on creation rather than subsequently adding it to the
   namespace.
 * This change supports kernels with limited namespace support
   (e.g. RHEL 6.5) so long as ovs_use_veth is set to True.
 * Addresses bug 1171727

Change-Id: I1885acc9934e7627bb9872703df7f5edf2980722

On the one hand, it means fewer backend requests when people use the wrong account in construction of a signed URL, but on the other hand, it means that you may not get that immediate success when you set up a key and make your first signed URL. If you made the signed URL before setting the key, the negative result would still be cached, and so it might look like it didn't work.

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-03 00:18:17.000000000', 'message': "Allow 2 TempURL keys per account.

This allows users to rotate their TempURL keys without invalidating
all existing signed URLs. This is handy if you have multiple systems
generating signed URLs, but you want to change your keys for some
reason (e.g. keys compromised, company policy, general paranoia).

Both the first and second keys are optional, so existing accounts'
signed URLs will continue to work as before.

This commit does change the memcache key used to store the fetched
TempURL keys. This is because we were storing the old key as a string
in memcached, but the new one is a list of keys. Since the key cache
lifetime here is only 60 seconds, it doesn't seem like too big a deal
to completely flush the TempURL cache.

Also, this commit adds caching of a negative TempURL result. If the
account HEAD reveals no TempURL keys at all, that result is now stored
for 60 seconds the same way that a positive result would be.

Change-Id: I40a02bd607283fbce11aa52a9bb8a5846ab17f5e

commit_message:
Allow 2 TempURL keys per account.

This allows users to rotate their TempURL keys without invalidating
all existing signed URLs. This is handy if you have multiple systems
generating signed URLs, but you want to change your keys for some
reason (e.g. keys compromised, company policy, general paranoia).

Both the first and second keys are optional, so existing accounts'
signed URLs will continue to work as before.

This commit does change the memcache key used to store the fetched
TempURL keys. This is because we were storing the old key as a string
in memcached, but the new one is a list of keys. Since the key cache
lifetime here is only 60 seconds, it doesn't seem like too big a deal
to completely flush the TempURL cache.

Also, this commit adds caching of a negative TempURL result. If the
account HEAD reveals no TempURL keys at all, that result is now stored
for 60 seconds the same way that a positive result would be.

Change-Id: I40a02bd607283fbce11aa52a9bb8a5846ab17f5e

commit_message:
Adds state reporting for utilization based scheduling

Extends state reporting to include up-to-date resource utilization of
hosts. Adds claims support and stats profiling to resource tracker.

Implements: blueprint utilization-based-scheduling

Change-Id: Ic9578fe7b59243c63cc5cd090b6bb6ff18b88c53

commit_message:
Doc changes for new pip-requirements

dnspython was added recently to the list of requirments.

This patch completes the change:
1. The new requirement is documented
2. The need for tox --recreate is documented
(assuming there is no way to automate 2 above)

Change-Id: I49f0cb4b01b79dd7cf4329984a2f8416378ebe19
Fixes: Bug #1176627

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-10 23:28:05.000000000', 'message': "Handle ints passed to `boolean_from_string`

The existing code would return True for '1' but False for int(1), unlike
Nova's version which would return True for both inputs.

Nova's version feels safer (i.e. it will do the most-likely-correct thing if
an int is passed in), so this patch changes Openstack-Common's version to
match.

Note that this patch does not make Openstack-Common's `boolean_from_string`
match Nova's `bool_from_string` exactly though. Nova's version would return
True for both '42' and 42, while Openstack-Common's returns False. Though
Nova's version, again, seems safer, the presence of unit-tests in
Openstack-Common asserting the defined-correctness of this behavior makes me
reluctant to change it.

Fixes bug 1178760

Change-Id: I8b2a31c4852884187bcbda3a4e78c8513b1bb8c8
"}, {'created': '2013-05-10 23:29:43.000000000', 'message': "Handle ints passed to `boolean_from_string`

Note that this patch does not make Openstack-Common's

commit_message:
Handle ints passed to `boolean_from_string`

The existing code would return True for '1' but False for int(1),
unlike Nova's version which would return True for both inputs.

Nova's version feels safer (i.e. it will do the most-likely-correct
thing if an int is passed in), so this patch changes
Openstack-Common's version to match.

Note that this patch does not make Openstack-Common's
`boolean_from_string` match Nova's `bool_from_string` exactly though.
Nova's version would return True for both '42' and 42, while
Openstack-Common's returns False. Though Nova's version, again, seems
safer, the presence of unit-tests in Openstack-Common asserting the
defined-correctness of this behavior makes me reluctant to change it.

Fixes bug 1178760

Change-Id: I8b2a31c4852884187bcbda3a4e78c8513b1bb8c8

commit_message:
make status_timeout a method

status_timeout was previously a function, which took an object as
the first parameter always. So it was called as:

test.status_timeout(self, ...)

which is craziness. If self is always the first param it should be
a method to make it.

self.status_timeout(...)

This is needed as part of the scenario refactoring.

part of bp:tempest-repo-restructure

Change-Id: I6c9570155e92711f99129e8e8736ddecc50e1f26

Here, let me play Jenkins for a second.

<Jenkins ish>
tox results:
  py26: commands succeeded
  py27: commands succeeded
  pep8: commands succeeded

devstack's probably failed for some dumb reason, tho
</Jenkins>

(The tests really do pass once you beat tox into installing posix_ipc.)"}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-04-18 18:01:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I suppose I should mention that this ssync method is going to be slower than the rsync method, but hopefully not too much slower in practice. Doing the request pipelining with the REPLICATION call gets rid of a ton of request round trip overhead, but it also means that the sender will send all objects in a suffix dir even if the remote only needs one of them.

So, ssync is really just experimental and to establish a baseline of correctness before moving on to the next stages.

With future improvements it is quite likely we'll have a list of objects the remote needs and only chance concurrency would end up with a useless transfer."}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-04-18 18:12:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-04-18 18:22:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-04-15 15:40:42.000000000', 'message': "Added ssync option for object replicator

This is just part one of likely many to implement
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/swift/+spec/object-replicator2

I'm doing my best to alter as little as possible, especially in the
unit tests. This is both to keep the review-patch to a minimum and to
ensure I don't introduce bugs the tests would've caught had I not
touched them. This does mean that some code that has moved modules
have not had their tests moved too. Also, some code may not be
exactly where or exactly formatted like we might want it eventually.
I'd like to leave such refactors to follow-on patches to keep this
one as small and confident as possible.

Here's an overview of what I changed and added:

New Requirement: posix_ipc>=0.9.4

    I don't much like having a new requirement, but it's the best way
    I could come up with to limit incoming concurrent REPLICATION
    requests. I'm definitely open to suggestions, although posix_ipc
    does seem pretty stable and has reasonable platform support.

Moved Functionality: To avoid circular imports

    Moved tpool_reraise from swift.obj.replicator to swift.common.utils.

    Moved get_hashes, HASH_FILE, hash_suffix, invalidate_hash,
    ONE_WEEK, PICKLE_PROTOCOL, quarantine_renamer from
    swift.obj.replicator to swift.obj.server.

Moved Config Items:

    Moved the conn_timeout, disk_chunk_size, network_chunk_size, and
    node_timeout configuration items in object-server.conf to the
    [DEFAULT] section so both the object-server and object-replicator
    (and any others) have access to them.

Object Replicator Changes:

    Renamed sync to rsync and made a new sync method that calls a
    configurable sync method.

    Created a new ssync method that works just like the rsync method
    but uses Swift-only functionality. This sends objects over using
    HTTP-based REPLICATION calls to the remote object server.
    REPLICATION calls are just a form of request pipelining for speed
    and to allow the remote host to more easily limit incoming
    replication.

Object Server Changes:

    Added new IterFile to change an iter into a file-like object that
    can be used as wsgi.input.

    Added REPLICATION method to accept new ssync type requests.

Change-Id: I778303d19582fe819a0f170f6667b7ac2dab9652
"}, {'created': '2013-04-18 18:12:34.000000000', 'message': "Added ssync option for object replicator

This is just part one of likely many to implement
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/swift/+spec/object-replicator2

I'm doing my best to alter as little as possible, especially in the
unit tests. This is both to keep the review-patch to a minimum and to
ensure I don't introduce bugs the tests would've caught had I not
touched them. This does mean that some code that has moved modules
have not had their tests moved too. Also, some code may not be
exactly where or exactly formatted like we might want it eventually.
I'd like to leave such refactors to follow-on patches to keep this
one as small and confident as possible.

Here's an overview of what I changed and added:

New Requirement: posix_ipc>=0.9.4

    I don't much like having a new requirement, but it's the best way
    I could come up with to limit incoming concurrent REPLICATION
    requests. I'm definitely open to suggestions, although posix_ipc
    does seem pretty stable and has reasonable platform support.

Moved Functionality: To avoid circular imports

    Moved tpool_reraise from swift.obj.replicator to swift.common.utils.

    Moved get_hashes, HASH_FILE, hash_suffix, invalidate_hash,
    ONE_WEEK, PICKLE_PROTOCOL, quarantine_renamer from
    swift.obj.replicator to swift.obj.server.

Moved Config Items:

    Moved the conn_timeout, disk_chunk_size, network_chunk_size, and
    node_timeout configuration items in object-server.conf to the
    [DEFAULT] section so both the object-server and object-replicator
    (and any others) have access to them.

Object Replicator Changes:

    Renamed sync to rsync and made a new sync method that calls a
    configurable sync method.

    Created a new EXPERIMENTAL ssync method that works just like the
    rsync method but uses Swift-only functionality. This sends
    objects over using HTTP-based REPLICATION calls to the remote
    object server. REPLICATION calls are just a form of request
    pipelining for speed and to allow the remote host to more easily
    limit incoming replication.

Object Server Changes:

    Added new IterFile to change an iter into a file-like object that
    can be used as wsgi.input.

    Added REPLICATION method to accept new ssync type requests.

Change-Id: I778303d19582fe819a0f170f6667b7ac2dab9652
"}, {'created': '2013-04-24 20:27:08.000000000', 'message': "Added ssync option for object replicator

This is just part one of likely many to implement
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/swift/+spec/object-replicator2

I'm doing my best to alter as little as possible, especially in the
unit tests. This is both to keep the review-patch to a minimum and to
ensure I don't introduce bugs the tests would've caught had I not
touched them. This does mean that some code that has moved modules
have not had their tests moved too. Also, some code may not be
exactly where or exactly formatted like we might want it eventually.
I'd like to leave such refactors to follow-on patches to keep this
one as small and confident as possible.

Here's an overview of what I changed and added:

New Requirement: posix_ipc>=0.9.4

    I don't much like having a new requirement, but it's the best way
    I could come up with to limit incoming concurrent REPLICATION
    requests. I'm definitely open to suggestions, although posix_ipc
    does seem pretty stable and has reasonable platform support.

Moved Functionality: To avoid circular imports

    Moved tpool_reraise from swift.obj.replicator to swift.common.utils.

    Moved get_hashes, HASH_FILE, hash_suffix, invalidate_hash,
    ONE_WEEK, PICKLE_PROTOCOL, quarantine_renamer from
    swift.obj.replicator to swift.obj.server.

Moved Config Items:

    Moved the conn_timeout, disk_chunk_size, network_chunk_size, and
    node_timeout configuration items in object-server.conf to the
    [DEFAULT] section so both the object-server and object-replicator
    (and any others) have access to them.

Object Replicator Changes:

    Renamed sync to rsync and made a new sync method that calls a
    configurable sync method.

    Created a new EXPERIMENTAL ssync method that works just like the
    rsync method but uses Swift-only functionality. This sends
    objects over using HTTP-based REPLICATION calls to the remote
    object server. REPLICATION calls are just a form of request
    pipelining for speed and to allow the remote host to more easily
    limit incoming replication.

Object Server Changes:

    Added new IterFile to change an iter into a file-like object that
    can be used as wsgi.input.

    Added REPLICATION method to accept new ssync type requests.

Change-Id: I778303d19582fe819a0f170f6667b7ac2dab9652

commit_message:
Added ssync option for object replicator

This is just part one of likely many to implement
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/swift/+spec/object-replicator2

I'm doing my best to alter as little as possible, especially in the
unit tests. This is both to keep the review-patch to a minimum and to
ensure I don't introduce bugs the tests would've caught had I not
touched them. This does mean that some code that has moved modules
have not had their tests moved too. Also, some code may not be
exactly where or exactly formatted like we might want it eventually.
I'd like to leave such refactors to follow-on patches to keep this
one as small and confident as possible.

Here's an overview of what I changed and added:

Moved Functionality: To avoid circular imports

    Moved tpool_reraise from swift.obj.replicator to swift.common.utils.

    Moved get_hashes, HASH_FILE, hash_suffix, invalidate_hash,
    ONE_WEEK, PICKLE_PROTOCOL, quarantine_renamer from
    swift.obj.replicator to swift.obj.server.

Moved Config Items:

    Moved the conn_timeout, disk_chunk_size, network_chunk_size, and
    node_timeout configuration items in object-server.conf to the
    [DEFAULT] section so both the object-server and object-replicator
    (and any others) have access to them.

Object Replicator Changes:

    Renamed sync to rsync and made a new sync method that calls a
    configurable sync method.

    Created a new EXPERIMENTAL ssync method that works just like the
    rsync method but uses Swift-only functionality. This sends
    objects over using HTTP-based REPLICATION calls to the remote
    object server. REPLICATION calls are just a form of request
    pipelining for speed and to allow the remote host to more easily
    limit incoming replication.

Object Server Changes:

    Added new IterFile to change an iter into a file-like object that
    can be used as wsgi.input.

    Added REPLICATION method to accept new ssync type requests.

Change-Id: I778303d19582fe819a0f170f6667b7ac2dab9652

commit_message:
Add notification for live migration

https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1167759

Currently, if live migration failed, nova compute did not send
notification, this caused other service such as nova-scheduler
has no chance to do some operation based on the result of live
migration.

The fix add notification logic for live_migration like other
VM instance operations such as resize, run instance etc.

Change-Id: I93db7599d5dab6a86aee070527bb5c18b44ba9d4

to run as with low privs it works just fine. As a side

commit_message:
Do not require sudo/rootwrap to check for dnsmasq version

The dnsmasq version check does not need root privileges
to run as with low privs it works just fine. As a side
effect, the use of the rootwrapper was causing unit tests
to hung because the execute call in check_version was not
being stubbed out. Weirdly enough this wasn't caught in
a previous Gerrit run; there must be a passwordless sudo
lurking around somewhere in the Gerrit infrastructure.

Fixes bug #1178800

Change-Id: I4d0bd218768eec2439d3907587682ff35884a262

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-04-02 23:10:59.000000000', 'message': 'Cache "qemu-img info" calls.

We ask qemu regularly if the virtual size of a disk image has changed,
yet the only time it actually will is if we resize the image. We can
therefore cache this information.

To achieve this, I've moved the recently added memoize decorator out
of the EC2 API and into utils. Doing that required making it a little
more generic as well.

Resolves bug 1154162.

Change-Id: I133619f4a2a2707a84b254e951d005689b69ba39
'}]
commit_message:
Cache "qemu-img info" calls.

We ask qemu regularly if the virtual size of a disk image has changed,
yet the only time it actually will is if we resize the image. We can
therefore cache this information.

To achieve this, I've moved the recently added memoize decorator out
of the EC2 API and into utils. Doing that required making it a little
more generic as well.

Resolves bug 1154162.

Change-Id: I133619f4a2a2707a84b254e951d005689b69ba39

Yes true that another way of thinking about it, from my perspective i was thinking of an Exception that could be raised when ever a libvirt operation fail, so it should be specific to libvirt code, that explain why i did it this way, but your way it to think of this exception as an exception that can be raised in all supported driver when a volume attachement fail, if i understand you correctly !? and that could work too, let's see what others will think about this :), i am still new at the nova code but i think your suggestion is more consistance with the code in nova."}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-04-17 20:57:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

What happens for other virt drivers besides libvirt?'}, {'account_id': 7073, 'date': '2013-04-18 09:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

As far as i can tell each driver handle this differently some swallow all exceptions raised when attaching a volume like Xen driver ! other raise a general exception like hyper-v driver.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2013-04-29 18:03:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

commit_message:
Raise a more significant error when volume attaching fail.

This patch raise a new exception rather than DeviceIsBusy error
to include more general cases while including the message returned
by libvirt library which is descriptive enough of where and what fail.

Change-Id: Ie0fc2880b75c139f74fddb6b50f66de70c8f296e
Fixes: LP#1168011

commit_message:
Remove clearfix class from dropdown-menus

clearfix applies display: block, which causes dropdown-menus
to always show.

Change-Id: I43fb70c22765dd9605a70e204342bb2e84536c19
Fixes: bug #1174048

The duplication in files/apts/* is to handle cases where individual services are installed.  For example, does a glance-only or swift-only install still require gcc?  (I'd hope not really but that's just an example.)  Anything appearing in files/apts/general shouldn't be anywhere else though.

As for the tools/build_* scripts (except build_tempest.sh), they were primarily used to support one of the original DevStack use cases that I don't think anyone is using any more."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-04-25 16:39:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Drop oneiric support

Ubuntu Oneiric will reach end of life support
on May 9, so drop the support in devstack.

Also remove duplicate packages in files/apts
when installing devstack on Ubuntu.

Change-Id: I5d79e3c67e4719bde3ee8a51dd656a8229bdbe4d
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-04-15 09:20:37.000000000', 'message': 'Keep snapshot in saving status after instance deleted

The snapshot would always be in the queued or SAVING status
after the VM is deleted or nova compute service is shutdown.
So I combined the review comments from the code review
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/24820 and review
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/25236, adding an error status
for image in glance, and make nove to update the glance image
status via python-glanceclient.

resolve bug 1143659
resolve bug 1064386

Change-Id: I21ee9c63ac9131acc9e819c7a018f7d90ecede41
'}]
commit_message:
Keep snapshot in saving status after instance deleted

The snapshot would always be in the queued or SAVING status
after the VM is deleted or nova compute service is shutdown.
So I combined the review comments from the code review
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/24820 and review
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/25236, adding an error status
for image in glance, and make nove to update the glance image
status via python-glanceclient.

resolve bug 1143659
resolve bug 1064386

Change-Id: I21ee9c63ac9131acc9e819c7a018f7d90ecede41

commit_message:
Check if domain_id present in user and tenant refs.

LDAP backend does not yet add domain_id to these refs. To make LDAP
backend work we need to check if such key exists prior to its usage.

Change-Id: I0caf554270df0f9f870579de439ef1bb7dff38fc

commit_message:
Change the type of "free_capacity_gb" to be float

Change the type of "free_capacity_gb" from string to float
in function _get_free_capacity.

Fix bug: 1177678

commit_message:
Make service tenant name configurable in keystone::roles::admin

Though "services" seems to be a fairly common name for the service
tenant, some people may prefer to use "service" or some other name.

The puppet-glance module, and others, do allow overriding the
service tenant name.

Change-Id: I4764cbf21821db96fac93ea4abdaf7d14bd12771

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-08 18:17:11.000000000', 'message': "update test runner to only run tempest/tests

we're restructuring tempest for clarity. one of the first changes
is bringing the cli directory in tempest proper:

see: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/28582/

this means we need to change the scope of tempest test running to
only be the tempest/tests directory for now. the alternative
approach to doing this with nosetests -e does not work nearly how
you would expect it. (Can't wait to get away from nose).

Change-Id: Idc775c3caff0284da8d7f735d76b3e50e39bb365

commit_message:
convert test runner to tox

We now have tox definitions for the test runs for tempest, which
lets us control the gate commands from tempest. Use tox to run
tempest in the gate now.

Part of bp:tempest-repo-restructure

Change-Id: Idc775c3caff0284da8d7f735d76b3e50e39bb365

commit_message:
proposal for tempest directory restructure

This is the text of a proposal for tempest directory restructure,
largely coming out of OpenStack summit. Once this has gotten core
sign off, I'llstart implementing the refactors into those
directories, and each will have a more specific README explaining
good tests in that kind of environment.

This proposal doesn't attempt to layout structure for tests we
don't have yet, this is entirely about organizing what we have into
something easier to understand. It is assumed new classes of tests
will get proposed over time, and we'll take them as they come.

Part of bp:tempest-repo-restructure

Change-Id: Ib8c55602b085622d322676ba2c24d9719fb9737d

commit_message:
Add sqlalchemy migration utils.create_shadow_table method

This method allows to create shadow table by existing table.

Two use cases:
a) create shadow table by table name
b) create shadow table from table instance

blueprint db-improve-archiving

Change-Id: Ib3a3797782b89a9a89baa60738edcabde7fe1299

commit_message:
Add sqlalchemy migration utils.check_shadow_table method

This method check that our table with name `xxx`:
1) Has shadow table `shadow_xxx`
2) All columns in `xxx` are also in `shadow_xxx` (with same type)
3) There is no extra columns in `shadow_xxx`

Will be used to check that all shadow tables are up-to-date.

blueprint db-improve-archiving

Change-Id: I0b366afe1b7d8703ab9c49a68977202b82d844fc

[{'created': '2013-05-10 07:02:25.000000000', 'message': 'Cleanup for test_create_server_with_deleted_image

Adds a cleanup for test_create_server_with_deleted_image so that
the test resets the test image to the active state after the test
finishes. Otherwise other tests which use the same image after
this test can fail.

Change-Id: Iedd039af54d2233d1afbc7fe2d21d1b3594c47b1
'}]
commit_message:
Cleanup for test_create_server_with_deleted_image

Adds a cleanup for test_create_server_with_deleted_image so that
the test resets the test image to the active state after the test
finishes. Otherwise other tests which use the same image after
this test can fail.

Change-Id: Iedd039af54d2233d1afbc7fe2d21d1b3594c47b1

commit_message:
only install things in the venv for pep8

we can use tox to run tempest, but to act like the gate we
shouldn't install a venv for full or smoke runs.

only do this for pep8, as we need hacking installed from pip

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-07 18:38:25.000000000', 'message': "Check cached SSH connection in PowerVM driver

The PowerVM operator code caches an SSH connection to the hypervisor
which can become invalid if the connection to the hypervisor is not
terminated cleanly, e.g. the hypervisor is rebooted while the compute
node is connected to it.

This code checks an existing SSH connection object to see if it's
transport is still alive and if not, re-establishes the connection
before attempting to run SSH commands on the hypervisor.

Also added some basic unit tests to cover the new check_connection
function in nova.virt.powervm.common.

Fixes bug 1177104

Change-Id: I08079cf0d9e60e1d8902d32d684d979b06f7f287

commit_message:
Check cached SSH connection in PowerVM driver

The PowerVM operator code caches an SSH connection to the hypervisor
which can become invalid if the connection to the hypervisor is not
terminated cleanly, e.g. the hypervisor is rebooted while the compute
node is connected to it.

This code checks an existing SSH connection object to see if it's
transport is still alive and if not, re-establishes the connection
before attempting to run SSH commands on the hypervisor.

Also added some basic unit tests to cover the new check_connection
function in nova.virt.powervm.common.

Fixes bug 1177104

Change-Id: I08079cf0d9e60e1d8902d32d684d979b06f7f287

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-10 21:25:46.000000000', 'message': 'move installation of mysql and pg drivers to run_tests.sh

the gate is currently switching to using tox to drive tempest,
making it possible for us to define what a full and smoke run are
like in the tempest tree.

However, in a full run only 1 database is installed, so tox fails
to bring in the venv for both databases, and explodes.

Move installing the db parts into run tests manually to get us
past the current blockage.

Change-Id: Idf3d495357f66c22287c42f3c84cd401c171ec94
'}]
commit_message:
move installation of mysql and pg drivers to run_tests.sh

the gate is currently switching to using tox to drive tempest,
making it possible for us to define what a full and smoke run are
like in the tempest tree.

However, in a full run only 1 database is installed, so tox fails
to bring in the venv for both databases, and explodes.

Move installing the db parts into run tests manually to get us
past the current blockage.

Change-Id: Idf3d495357f66c22287c42f3c84cd401c171ec94

[{'created': '2013-05-10 21:58:52.000000000', 'message': "Server: correctly set Keystone service password

$keystone_password does not exist as a class parameter,
$auth_password does. The previous behavior would result in perpetual
authentication failures when Quantum would try to authenticate to
Keystone with the literal '%SERVICE_PASSWORD%' as the password.

Change-Id: Ie89eecb3efab61ca9fa280b4a5bc530d1053d074
"}]
commit_message:
Server: correctly set Keystone service password

$keystone_password does not exist as a class parameter,
$auth_password does. The previous behavior would result in perpetual
authentication failures when Quantum would try to authenticate to
Keystone with the literal '%SERVICE_PASSWORD%' as the password.

Change-Id: Ie89eecb3efab61ca9fa280b4a5bc530d1053d074

commit_message:
Allow different paths for deploy-helper helpers.

Different distros (or even distro releases) put iscsiadm in potentially
arbitrary paths. It is better to use rootwraps' own search than to hardcode the
path.

Fixes bug 1178612

Change-Id: I690788b666a84e599504690d0e2d087eaa66a4c8

commit_message:
Show exception details for failed deploys.

Without some detail errors are inscrutable and impossible to debug.

Fixes bug 1178608

Change-Id: I0ed6164e8689c63bd194924d3f7cb50b49feb921

commit_message:
Add unitests for VMware vif, and fix code logical error.

Fix code logical error that cause variable referenced before assignment.
Add unittests for vmwareapi vif.

Fix bug #1177635

Change-Id: I6656e8b77417061eca2a56d50820f5385c0ae987

subject: Allow a floating IP to be associated to a specific fixed IP
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 191, 'name': 'Trey Morris', 'email': 'trey.morris@rackspace.com', 'username': 'tr3buchet'}, {'_account_id': 1501, 'name': 'Phil Day', 'email': 'philip.day@hp.com', 'username': 'philip-day'}, {'_account_id': 1528, 'name': 'Stanislaw Pitucha', 'email': 'viraptor@gmail.com', 'username': 'stanislaw-pitucha'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2750, 'name': 'Sean Dague', 'email': 'sean@dague.net', 'username': 'sdague'}, {'_account_id': 4393, 'name': 'Dan Smith', 'email': 'dms@danplanet.com', 'username': 'danms'}, {'_account_id': 4395, 'name': 'Aaron Rosen', 'email': 'aaronorosen@gmail.com', 'username': 'arosen'}]

'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2013-04-04 19:40:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Code seems good, I'm just wondering if this needs to be a new extension."}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-04-05 09:33:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi Vish,

Let me help by making the case against this becoming an extension to an extension :-)

I think it would be confusing to users and add no real value to create an additional “add floating IP” action to servers, so the scope of an extension would presumably be to act as a switch to parsing or ignoring the additional “fixed_address” parameter.  There is no change in any response message, so no need for an extension to maintain compatibility there.

Because this is implanted as an optional parameter the API remains 100% backwards compatible – even with this change in place the system behaves exactly as it did before for all inputs except if the new parameter is specified.

A new extension really feels overkill in this context for what is a long standing “todo” item,'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-04-05 17:28:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

BTW I have the matching nova-client change ready to go, but thought this needed to go through first'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2013-04-05 17:38:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

An extension wouldn't need to be functionally different. It could still allow adding an extra parameter to the code. The main use case is allowing users to determine whether or not the extra field is supported. That said nothing would break sending the extra parameter to the old code, it would just be ignored. For that reason I think I'm ok just adding this as is, but I would like other people to weigh in."}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-04-05 18:05:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

My major concern is the following scenario.

You get an April nova client, you try to use it with grizzly, and you give it this client flag. How do you know that that parameter isn't supported?

Was just tripping over a nova client command that fell on it's face like this in Folsom for similar reasons.

I think that until we do better with extensions (have some baked in versioning) the extension to the extension is the only safe way to do this.

It does suck, but we have stated that we care about client compatibility with older servers."}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-04-05 20:35:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

So would the acceptable approach to be:

i) Copy floating_ips.py to floating_ips_v2.py, and give is a new class name, so it still registers at the same endpoint but the user (and the python client) can tell from the list of extensions which version is loaded

or 

ii) Add get_version() function to the existing extension that the client can call to which version is loaded

or 

iii) Something else ?


i) Sounds like it would be fairly easy but pretty clumsy (I guess I'd have to replicate all of the test code as well)

Seems like ii) might be cleaner and something we need to consider in general for extensions."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2013-04-05 23:11:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

The "right" way is something like this:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/23667/'}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2013-04-06 00:10:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

hiya Phil! Since I put the original TODO in place ages ago, I'm glad it's finally being taken care of. In terms of weighing in on the extension mechanism by which this TODO is addressed, I'm going to side with Phil's original argument against the extension to the extension.

As to Sean's scenario, this is an optional parameter, so if using a newer client with a previous nova release, as the commit says, "API behaviour is unchanged". So no unexpected behaviors are being added. There is just a chance that one of the parameters the client knows about might not yet be supported by nova. That is an easy, and clean, fix in the client. Just have it expect that an error will be raised if the nova deployment doesn't support that paramater yet (for backwards compatibility) and display an appropriate message: "fixed_ip address parameter not supported in this nova release. Try your request again without it, noting that the floating ip may be pseudorandomly associated with one of your fixed ips if multiple exist for this instance/network combo" or some such.

I think I tend to think about API changes in a less rigid way than the community at large, so I'll probably get outvoted (hence a +1), but I prefer the cleaner route where we make the client backwards compatible with this change. If we keep bending over backwards in nova to make sure lack of backwards compatibility features in the client can't bite us, the [flawed] client will never be fixed.

We need to write clients that can handle our service API versions instead of writing the service APIs to support the clients.'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-04-06 06:49:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hi Trey,

> That is an easy, and clean, fix in the client. Just 
> have it expect that an error will be raised if the nova
> deployment doesn't support that paramater yet (for 
> backwards compatibility)

I think the issue is that as things stand the client has no way of finding out if the parameter is supported or not - since the current code silently ignores any extra parameters. 

I could make the client verify that the floating address has   been assigned to the requested fixed IP, and undo the assignment if not. (Sort of have the client infer the version by inspecting behaviour) ?"}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-04-06 06:56:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi Vish, 

> The "right" way is something like this:
> https://review.openstack.org/#/c/23667/

Seems to me that there is something wrong when the" right" way requires 430 lines of code to add a single extra bit of information to an existing API call.  :-)

Plus in that case there was a change in the data being returned, which I can see could upset some client code.

This change is trying to make the system behave more predictably.'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-04-08 09:45:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hi Sean,

If I make the client verify that the floating address has been assigned to the requested fixed IP, and undo the assignment if not would that address your concern about client compatibility with Nova Systems which don't including this change ? 

Maybe not quiet a elegant as having some explicit versioning of the extension but it would be a lot simpler and cleaner on the Nova side that creating another extension, and the logic would still be in the client in either case.

Phil"}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2013-04-09 20:47:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I would prefer making the client fail if an argument isn't supported rather than to perform an action, double check results, and possibly perform the opposite action depending on the result. The latter just seems incredibly messy. Especially with multiple systems involved and notifications and what not."}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-04-12 19:08:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi Trey,

I think they only way you could do that is to make this a specific additional extension then (the extension on extension model) and have the client check that the extension is available in the API.  

The client still has to have all of the logic to infer that the additional parameter is supported (i.e it has to be built in that extension name "xxx" means that the API supports parameter "yyy") - so I'm not convinced that this simplifies the client any, and it just means a more code on the Nova API side to achieve the same result.

Guess this will have to fester for a bit longer then until I get the time to make it a separate extension'}, {'account_id': 4395, 'date': '2013-04-13 01:41:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1528, 'date': '2013-04-15 18:04:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

Small suggestion'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-04-22 13:35:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-04-22 13:41:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-04-22 14:30:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed.  For information on how to proceed, see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GerritJenkinsGithub#Test_Failures

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-04-04 17:12:12.000000000', 'message': 'Allow a floating IP to be associated to a specific fixed IP

The current floating IP API extension only accepts the instance ID
and the floating address to be assigned. Where the instance is
connected to more than one network the behaviour is to associated
the floating IP with the first fixed IP of the instances
(and to log a warning)

This change adds a fixed IP address as an optional parameter,
allowing the floating IP to be associated with a specific fixed IP.

Without this optional parameter the API behaviour is unchanged.

If specified the fixed IP must be associated with the instance.

DocImpact

Implements blueprint multi-nic-floating-ip-assignment

Change-Id: I9241137ad794cdf7f452ed84e9445f0e11fdd44e

commit_message:
Allow a floating IP to be associated to a specific fixed IP

The current floating IP API extension only accepts the instance ID
and the floating address to be assigned. Where the instance is
connected to more than one network the behaviour is to associated
the floating IP with the first fixed IP of the instances
(and to log a warning)

This change introduces a new extension which wehn loaded adds a
fixed IP address as an optional parameter, allowing the floating
IP to be associated with a specific fixed IP.

Without this extension, or without the optional parameters,
the API behaviour is unchanged.

If specified the fixed IP must be associated with the instance.

DocImpact

Implements blueprint multi-nic-floating-ip-assignment

Change-Id: I9241137ad794cdf7f452ed84e9445f0e11fdd44e

Indeed they are similar.  This patch covers the same optimizations, while also addressing the data loss issue covered in my bug report.

Also, the justification for SSH here is that to do the shared file system check like we do for live migrations requires a set of RPC calls.  I agree that's a much better/cleaner approach but it's a lot more change for code which is ultimately going away this cycle.  Thus, the thought is to be consistently bad (use SSH), as it is all over the migrate/resize code, until the full refactor is complete."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-07 16:26:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Make resize/migrated shared storage aware

Fixes bug 1177247

Added some logic to check for whether or not we are on a shared
filesystem and set shared_storage accordingly. We perform similar
checks in other areas of the code, typically through RPC calls.
However, all the resize/migrate code is slated to be refactored for
Hava, so the idea was to keep this patch as minimally intrusive as
possible.

When shared_storage is true, we pass that on to the cleanup call
so that it no longer executes an rm via SSH, which was ultimately
destroying the original instance directory.

Change-Id: Ie9decedd373c000211c171df64e1e96fe78e5081

commit_message:
Enabling assertions disabled for bug #1074901

Bug #1074901 was fixed allowing us to enable some assertions in

commit_message:
Implement a proxy checker class.

Add a proxy checker class for local checks that doesn't do anything,
but instead registers a command option that allows for local, in-tree
checks.

Change-Id: I3f7567639ae47cc422c84f319f1b607ad193d901
Reviewed-on: https://review.openstack.org/28220
Reviewed-by: James E. Blair <corvus@inaugust.com>
Reviewed-by: Giampaolo Lauria <lauria@us.ibm.com>
Reviewed-by: Sean Dague <sean@dague.net>
Approved: Joe Gordon <jogo@cloudscaling.com>
Reviewed-by: Joe Gordon <jogo@cloudscaling.com>
Tested-by: Jenkins

http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 694, 'date': '2013-05-10 19:39:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

If the temp file is random it means there's an arbitrary decision to put a garbage file somewhere. It seems better to make the user specify it. 

For example, in Tox it makes sense for this to live in Tox's temp directory, but in the VM it might fit better in /tmp. Plus, the user already has to specify where xmllint lives. It just doesn't seem like something doable with default values so I don't get what the problem is asking them to specify where the file lives as well."}, {'account_id': 739, 'date': '2013-05-10 19:39:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

why not use a tempfile and _not_ have anything config based?'}, {'account_id': 739, 'date': '2013-05-10 19:39:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1925, 'date': '2013-05-10 19:39:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 4240, 'date': '2013-05-10 19:39:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I don't like that you require a config value for the XML temp file. How about just using a random temp file? At least if it doesn't exist in the config?"}, {'account_id': 4240, 'date': '2013-05-10 19:39:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

yeah i guess that makes sense and if we auto configure that with reddwarf-integration in most cases.'}, {'account_id': 6268, 'date': '2013-05-10 19:39:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-10 19:39:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

commit_message:
Adding ability to run XmlLint for each API call.

This will not run in Tox normally, but makes that idea possible.
See the following for more details:
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Reddwarf-Test-With-XmlLint

Change-Id: Ifc675b6955b1e5d5e32c98968f1444de9dffe14c
implements: blueprint xmllint-verification

commit_message:
Raise jsonschema requirement to 1.0.0+

jsonschema library version 1.0.0+ supports JsonSchema-Draft4
specification, and blueprint nova-api-validation-fw needs it
for strict API validation.

Change-Id: Ie6f2fec6f71d7cdc4129433606e5a5f4cc81186c
