I got a workable regex pattern which can combine the " and ':
_RE_PASS = re.compile(r'([\'"].*?password[\'"]\s*:\s*u?[\'"]).*?([\'"])', re.DOTALL)
But as I mentioned, it will not easy to maintain IMHO.'}, {'account_id': 6486, 'date': '2013-04-12 17:57:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(5 inline comments)

looks good, just would like clarification on the regex."}, {'account_id': 4992, 'date': '2013-04-12 18:39:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Thanks David for your clarification on why unicode.

Good work on _RE_PASS = re.compile(r'([\'"].*?password[\'"]\s*:\s*u?[\'"]).*?([\'"])', re.DOTALL) 

Actually [a-z] type stuff for a single character in a set is pretty common, it just looks a little complicated because replicated multiple times, and needing to special case the double quote with backslash. A little documentation would help in maintenance.
Should you add a * immediately after the ], you are saying no quotes fine too.
(I believe this is essentially why you had the first * in your patterns, to say it is OK not to have the "password" or 'password'.

The pros, now that you have done the hard work is that you skip a second regular expression check. Further you are allowing mixing of use or " and '
that is
"password" : 'my-secret'
'password' : "my-secret"
in addition to the ones you have listed.

Certainly do not need the == to check whether to re-apply the regex test  as Brant mentions.

Thank you again.
Malini


Regards
Malini'}, {'account_id': 6526, 'date': '2013-04-13 08:28:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: (4 inline comments)

Thanks for you guys' comments.

Actually, the reason why i have * before the password means we have 'original_password' in keystone.contrib.user_crud module as Dolph mentioned in my patch 2. But I missed one . before the *.
Please reexam my new patch."}, {'account_id': 6526, 'date': '2013-04-13 08:40:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-04-13 09:26:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2013-04-17 05:52:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

Should this be done by a log filter? See

http://docs.python.org/2/library/logging.html#filter-objects'}, {'account_id': 6526, 'date': '2013-04-17 07:21:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

To consider the performance issue, I don't think add log filter is a better solution, any thought?"}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2013-04-17 14:25:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

Log filter gives you consistency and centralized control. Is this the only place password is logged? What if someone decided to log password, or any sensitive information, elsewhere in the future?

I would even argue that security-related log filters needs to be in Oslo.

Obviously there are trade-offs in our design decision. But is rather difficult to debate performance without any kind of benchmarks. What's our baseline? What's the threshold?"}, {'account_id': 4992, 'date': '2013-04-18 06:38:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: No score

Good suggestion Guang-Yee to use log filters. It is a rich infrastructure allowing for useful extras like "aspect" programming. 

This has a nice example: http://docs.python.org/2/howto/logging-cookbook.html#filters-contextual

with essentially defining a password_filter(self, record) that invokes the re code and substitution you defined David.

From a performance standpoint, David's current implementation will run faster because the regex matching and sustitution is invoked only when the loglevel == debug as opposed to always.

Guang-yee, did you intend for password masking for all OpenStack components in your log filter suggestion?
That is, will password occur in other places?

The only common ancestor off all the openstack loggers to be the base logging class. various loggers seem to all be descendants of the primary logger, not some package level common logger.
If it is possible to attach the filter to all our loggers via
   a_logger =  logging.getLogger(__name__)


   f = PasswordMaskerFilter()
   a_logger.addFilter(f)

then we are lucky, else will need to modify a lot of files.
There are a few different calls such as 

glance/glance/common/wsgi.py:        self.logger = os_logging.
getLogger('eventlet.wsgi.server')


A little digression .. there was a blueprint for a gloabl request-id to be passed around for logging and correlation purposes and Yahoo at the summit demo-ed a logging solution which provided similar functionality. The log filter approach may be a simple solution to this need.

Regards
Malini'}, {'account_id': 6526, 'date': '2013-04-18 07:15:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

Malini/Guang-yee, thanks a lot for your comments.

For the bug 1166697, I think I already address the issue.

For Guang-yee's suggestion, we need further discussion and maybe need combine with Yahoo's solution. If mask password or other sensitive information is common requirement of all the components I think we can contribute it into oslo."}, {'account_id': 4992, 'date': '2013-04-18 17:23:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Based on Dolph's response, this fix is plenty.
Much thanks David and Dolph!
Malini
=============
From: Dolph Mathews [mailto:dolph.mathews@gmail.com] 
Sent: Thursday, April 18, 2013 8:00 AM
To: OpenStack Development Mailing List
Subject: Re: [openstack-dev] passwords in logs --security related

1) passwords are currently logged by keystone when you enable debug mode (and there's a big warning in the sample.conf about passwords in plain text)
2) the fix is very specific to the identity api's json presentation of passwords
3) if any other service is handling passwords, then we're doing something very wrong

I don't see a reason for anything to go into oslo?



-Dolph

On Thu, Apr 18, 2013 at 1:48 AM, Bhandaru, Malini K <malini.k.bhandaru@intel.com> wrote:
Hello All!
 
David Geng is addressing a case of password logging in keystone. Do we handle any passwords in other openstack
components and log them?  Might they benefit from David moving his fix into Oslo as a log filter (a nice suggestion from Guang-yee).
Please weigh in. If yes, what is expected the string pattern?
 
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/26487/
 
 
Regards
Malini"}, {'account_id': 994, 'date': '2013-04-18 17:59:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1803, 'date': '2013-04-19 14:35:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

request body output

subject: Refactor of puppet-quantum
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-09 01:14:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/28268/1/check/gate-puppet-quantum-puppet-unit-2.6/36 : SUCCESS in 00:00:33
- http://logs.openstack.org/28268/1/check/gate-puppet-quantum-puppet-unit-2.7/36 : SUCCESS in 00:00:31
- http://logs.openstack.org/28268/1/check/gate-puppet-quantum-puppet-unit-3.0/36 : SUCCESS in 00:00:30
- http://logs.openstack.org/28268/1/check/gate-puppet-quantum-puppet-unit-3.1/36 : SUCCESS in 00:00:28
'}, {'account_id': 2265, 'date': '2013-05-09 01:14:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

I gave it a quick look-over. I am slightly concerned that it's too hard to review as is b/c it conflates a large number of fixes.

Specifically it conflates:
  - adding needed documentation to parameters
  - making changes that are specific to features in grizzly
  - fixing things that were previously incorrect or missing.

I will probably have time to properly review next week, but I would be happy if someone else can review.

It also seems to not add: examples/create_network.sh as promised. I had a minitor question about the puppet code."}, {'account_id': 2813, 'date': '2013-05-09 01:14:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(3 inline comments)

The patch is really hard to read, and it does many different things. Perhaps it should be split, one for formatting/refactoring and some other for new features.

But all this changes seems good and needed"}, {'account_id': 3217, 'date': '2013-05-09 01:14:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(20 inline comments)

That was cathartic.  Comments vary from questions on what you were doing to questions on what I was doing, so there's a mixed bag in there.

I would agree with others that the mixed change set (specifically, the whitespace changes throughout) do make it hard to review.

Additionally, while I totally agree that the qemu hack (which is Ubuntu-specific, anyway) doesn't belong in here, the fact that it doesn't work properly without it says to me that removing it isn't the right answer."}, {'account_id': 3217, 'date': '2013-05-09 01:14:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Yeah - I wouldn't say this was the right place for it, necessarily - though you'll note that the way we did it was to allow quantum to update the file but only if the file had been installed via libvirt, hence the virtual resource.  

I don't know about the other components, and certainly wholesale replacement of the file is unsuitable (but at least the conflict you'd get if you tried it should make that clear).  Probably we need some sort of qemu.conf type/provider.  

I don't believe there would ever be two components anywhere within Openstack that would want to add tuntap to the cgroup at the same time - it's net-related, so whatever Quantum plugin, or nova-network settings, you're using should determine if it's necessary - implying that the act of setting it (possibly by instantiating a class or define from elsewhere) should be in the networking code.  That does rather assume that you're *only* installing openstack on the node, though, if you're doing weird libvirt shite on there you could reasonably want it enabled from there as well."}, {'account_id': 3217, 'date': '2013-05-09 01:14:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Going to read this in a minute, but my immediate comment (on reading the commit notes) is that while qemu.conf is a dirty hack, removing it doesn't actually improve anything.  Propose a better method for dealing with the problem by all means, but don't just take it out.

Similarly rootwrap.conf - I haven't run this to check, but is the rootwrap.conf being inserted exactly the same as the rootwrap.conf that the distribution supplies?"}, {'account_id': 3217, 'date': '2013-05-09 01:14:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: No score

The bug was a on the Cisco module this is derived from and is:

https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-cisco/+bug/1086255

Basically, if you're using 'ethernet' type (rather than 'bridge' type) network interfaces in your libvirt.xml - which is standard with some vNIC drivers - then you need to change qemu.conf to fix the listed section or it doesn't permit kvm to use the tuntap devices it needs."}, {'account_id': 6859, 'date': '2013-05-09 01:14:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Work In Progress

Mostly for discussion / review. Please do not merge yet.'}, {'account_id': 6859, 'date': '2013-05-09 01:14:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (8 inline comments)

Ian, Thank you for your comments. They're much appreciated. This is exactly the kind of review I was looking for. I wanted to upload the module as how I thought it should work (and got it to work in my environment) and wanted to see if any major red flags were raised at the high level on if this was totally bad.

Please see my replies to most of your comments. Please also take a read through my notes in the puppet-openstack mailing list. I do disagree with the agent/plugin separation but I know I am missing a piece to this puzzle.

I'll take a look at the bug you've linked and work it into the module if it's still valid."}, {'account_id': 6859, 'date': '2013-05-09 01:14:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I agree with all of that.

You're absolutely right about other components and "tuntap", too, but I was thinking of the "other" components clobbering the changes that Quantum made. If I remember right, nova used to bundle its own qemu.conf file and then switched to file_line ... maybe I am thinking of another module, but I know I've seen it elsewhere.

Given all of this, I am happy to add this back in with a link to the bug report. I overlooked the benefit of the virtual resource, too, so I think that works just as good as a flag would.

Thank you for clarifying this. I apologize for the bluntness of totally removing it, but admittedly it's the best way to get an answer.  :)'}, {'account_id': 6859, 'date': '2013-05-09 01:14:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I've never run into the qemu.conf issue and the notes in the manifest gave no indication of what problem was occurring.

If someone knows what problem it was trying to solve, please let me know and I'd be happy to wrap some logic around it to isolate it to the narrow use case + use file_line instead of the entire file. Otherwise, I'm chalking it up to a pre-Grizzly issue.

rootwrap.conf is correctly installed with the quantum packages. Same theme as qemu.conf - it should really use file_line or something similar instead of the entire file."}, {'account_id': 6859, 'date': '2013-05-09 01:14:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (3 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 6859, 'date': '2013-05-09 01:14:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

OK, I just read the bug report and saw the notorious qemu cgroup device acl block. :)

I say "notorious" because this block is requested to be added to qemu.conf by other areas of openstack. I believe it used to be in the nova module, but it looks like it has been removed.

Given the notoriety, I think it should be removed from the module since it could cause a resource conflict. Or maybe a parameter flag could be added to allow quantum to work on qemu.conf? That might be a safe solution.'}, {'account_id': 6859, 'date': '2013-05-09 01:14:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Only submitted for review. That's been done."}]

This commit introduces several changes to the quantum puppet module:

  * Rewrites the README.md file
  * Fixes the example manifest
  * Adds examples/create_network.sh as a quick helper script until
    proper types/providers are made.
  * Removes rootwrap.conf. This should be packaged by the distribution.
  * Removes the qemu.conf file from manifests/init.pp. This is not the

  * Renames two variables in params.pp to something more intuitive.
  * Renames auth_password to keystone_password in manifests/server.pp

  * Fixes tenant specification in keystone/auth.pp
  * Removes UUIDs specified in agents/l3.pp
  * Adds external bridge creation in agents/l3.pp
  * Adds metadata_ip to agents/l3.pp
  * Adds firewall support in manifests/agents/ovs.pp
  * Lots of formatting and restructuring

Change-Id: Ifc4325f7d472a3fd78f7b379b5095b974874909b
'}]
commit_message:
Refactor of puppet-quantum

This commit introduces several changes to the quantum puppet module:

  * Rewrites the README.md file
  * Fixes the example manifest
  * Adds examples/create_network.sh as a quick helper script until
    proper types/providers are made.
  * Removes rootwrap.conf. This should be packaged by the distribution.
  * Removes the qemu.conf file from manifests/init.pp. This is not the
    right place for this file and packaging a full qemu.conf file into
    this module is not a good idea.
  * Renames two variables in params.pp to something more intuitive.
  * Renames auth_password to keystone_password in manifests/server.pp
    as this is the naming scheme used in other modules.
  * Fixes tenant specification in keystone/auth.pp
  * Removes UUIDs specified in agents/l3.pp
  * Adds external bridge creation in agents/l3.pp
  * Adds metadata_ip to agents/l3.pp
  * Adds firewall support in manifests/agents/ovs.pp
  * Lots of formatting and restructuring

Change-Id: Ifc4325f7d472a3fd78f7b379b5095b974874909b

commit_message:
Changes the OVS plugin/agent

This patch makes the following changes to the OVS plugin/agent:

  * Adds doc heads
  * Adds firewall driver support
  * Allows GRE to be setup without VLANs
  * Renames the plugin package to a more intuitive name
  * General format/code cleanup

Change-Id: I96080171a9b6e252510ce62351db98926f754c31

commit_message:
Remove subscribe on cinder.conf

This is already taken care of with this relationship in the same file:
  Cinder_config<||> ~> Service['cinder-scheduler']

Change-Id: I7bae966b058e63af29d5c6f37bd5f26c6b08f34b

commit_message:
Run cfn-hup via a cron job.

cfn-hup is supposed to be a daemon, but it doesn't work that way. So run
it via a wrapper in a cron job. Also run this way, we won't have
logging, so make sure os-refresh-config is run via upstart so we get the
output logged.

The wrapper must use a lock to avoid problems that might be caused when
multiple updates overlap.

Change-Id: I8613c45b33091ad6448ecddebe6a1f4337f09d7d

Ok, lets give it a spin. It does seem a little ugly still, sadly (but thats not your fault ;)).'}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2013-05-08 22:38:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2013-05-08 22:38:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@lifeless:

1) Yes I gave it a try on Ubuntu and builded an image, also checked if variables like http_proxy are being preserved[1] and it seems all good. Last time I think it didn't work out because I was expanding the PATH variable in the first users shell during argument processing and giving it to the sudo command, so the PATH variable inside the chroot had the same value as the user's PATH variable. Now, I'm preserving PATH syntax until after the sh command runs, so all it does is append /usr/local/bin to the PATH variable inside the chroot.

ps*: I also checked if the http_proxy variable were being passed to the chroot.

2) I didn't consider it because I'd like it to be transparent for the user. But yea, in the worst case scenario that's an option.

I also thought about some other solutions like creating a mechanism to write those variables in a file and then source it inside the chroot, but I think it's overkill, sudo -E works fine for any enviroment variable. A quick googling about sudo and $PATH will show you that these two have a long love story together.

[1]
ubuntu@ubuntu-virtual-machine:/tmp/diskimage-builder$ sudo bin/disk-image-create -o test base
ubuntu@ubuntu-virtual-machine:/tmp/diskimage-builder$ sudo qemu-nbd -c /dev/nbd0 test.qcow2
ubuntu@ubuntu-virtual-machine:/tmp/diskimage-builder$ mkdir /tmp/img
ubuntu@ubuntu-virtual-machine:/tmp/diskimage-builder$ sudo mount /dev/nbd0 /tmp/img/

ubuntu@ubuntu-virtual-machine:/tmp/diskimage-builder$ echo $PATH
/usr/local/sbin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/sbin:/usr/bin:/sbin:/bin:/usr/games:/usr/local/games

ubuntu@ubuntu-virtual-machine:/tmp/diskimage-builder$ sudo -E chroot /tmp/img/
root@ubuntu-virtual-machine:/# echo $PATH
/usr/local/sbin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/sbin:/usr/bin:/sbin:/bin
root@ubuntu-virtual-machine:/# exit

ubuntu@ubuntu-virtual-machine:/tmp/diskimage-builder$ export http_proxy="testing"
ubuntu@ubuntu-virtual-machine:/tmp/diskimage-builder$ cmd="PATH=\$PATH:/usr/local/bin ; echo \$PATH ; echo \$http_proxy"
ubuntu@ubuntu-virtual-machine:/tmp/diskimage-builder$ sudo -E chroot /tmp/img/ sh -c "$cmd"
/usr/local/sbin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/sbin:/usr/bin:/sbin:/bin:/usr/local/bin
testing'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-08 22:38:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

commit_message:
Force the inclusion of /usr/local/bin in PATH.

Sudo compiled with the --with-secure-path option enabled (default on
Ubuntu, Fedora and potentially other distros) will cause sudo to ignore
any changes made to the PATH variable in the user's environment (even when
the -E option is used). Also, some distros might not have /usr/local/bin
set in their sudoers secure_path causing the diskimage-builder to fail
when building an image using such distros as host. This patch will force
the inclusion of the /usr/local/bin in the PATH enviroment variable
inside the chroot.

Change-Id: Idb7156d8ff124bfe685cc721337d9bb21f49dc9e
Fixes: bug #1175980

commit_message:
Fix /32 subnet creation to work properly

Currently when creates subnet with /32 cidr, allocation pool
and gateway are set incorrect. For /32 cidr, DHCP should be
disabled and gateway should be set None.

Change-Id: Ifbdad9a2187c9cfcc88380e812f384566151d424
Fixes: bug #1177196

commit_message:
Session cleanup for db.floating_ip_* methods

Session objects shouldn't be used in public db.api methods
because db.api should be independent of db implementation.

Remove session parameter from:
  floating_ip_create
  floating_ip_get_by_fixed_ip_id

I didn't remove session parameter from floating_ip_count_by_project
because it causes changes in nova.quota. So it will be done in
separated patch.

Cleanup test for floating_ip_count_by_project removed 3rd
parameter (it should be session, but it is not required).

blueprint db-session-cleanup

Change-Id: Ifdf9edb17746a8e5b486317c917ea69016a2b99d

'}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2013-05-07 11:58:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I think the original intention is that admins should be able to see the "details" of a fault (including the traceback) but other end users will not. I'm not sure if this is still the case or not.'}, {'account_id': 6999, 'date': '2013-05-07 20:40:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thanks Alex for the input. This line of current code: 
details += '\n' + ''.join(traceback.format_tb(tb)) adds the trace logs into the fault details and show the whole thing to users who have permission to the tenant the image was created in. Users who does not have permission will not be able to see anything at all. This code change will remove the trace logs from the fault messages that being shown to the users who has permission to run the cli command."}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2013-05-08 00:05:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I have the same understanding as Alex, that fault details are supposed to include a traceback that is visible only to admin users.

One use case for this is cluster admin can check details of a failure without having to go to log files.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-05-08 07:37:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Do not merge

Yes, the traceback is in the fault on purpose.  It should only be displayed to admins.'}, {'account_id': 6999, 'date': '2013-05-08 20:41:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

works as designed'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-07 06:40:49.000000000', 'message': 'Remove stack trace logs from fault message

In case of Nova fails to deploy an image, when user run
cli command like "nova show image-name" it will show the
exception class name, the detail message that is thrown from
the exception class, and also the stack trace logs.

End-user does not need to see the stack trace logs, this should be
seen in nova compute log files.

This fix will remove the stack trace logs from fault message.

Fixes bug 1177205

Change-Id: I39323beef69485a1c37e5a46fb448a292d9941e0
'}]
commit_message:
Remove stack trace logs from fault message

In case of Nova fails to deploy an image, when user run
cli command like "nova show image-name" it will show the
exception class name, the detail message that is thrown from
the exception class, and also the stack trace logs.

End-user does not need to see the stack trace logs, this should be
seen in nova compute log files.

This fix will remove the stack trace logs from fault message.

Fixes bug 1177205

Change-Id: I39323beef69485a1c37e5a46fb448a292d9941e0

commit_message:
Extend mellanox support to disk images.

We need to support mellanox devices in disk images as well as ramdisks.
This adds the requisite element structure to provide that support.

Change-Id: Iaf383f5b32b84fbb69569ef42ec2460ab1b231e5

commit_message:
Remove img-functions from ramdisk-image-create.

Ramdisk-image-create sources both img-functions and ramdisk-functions
causing duplicate functions. To correct this situation this patch
removes the import of img-functions from ramdisk-image-create.
It moves cleanup_dirs and run_d functions from img-functions to
common-functions to allow this.

fixes bug 1175427
Authored-by: Chris Krelle <nobodycam@gmail.com>

Change-Id: I971d019b0d92b06d9de661663b49c433e823ea42

commit_message:
Ignore errors when ldd'ing static binaries.

When trying to get the library dependencies from a static program
it fails and die.
This scapes the error and continue with the execution.

Change-Id: Id3463f2dd77a182ce4f9d9d28165d35f17806892

[{'created': '2013-05-08 15:43:29.000000000', 'message': 'Remove insecure default for signing_dir option.

The sample api-paste.ini file included an insecure value for the
signing_dir option for the keystone authtoken middleware.  Comment out
the option so that we just rely on the default behavior by default.

Fix bug 1174608.

Change-Id: I6189788953d789c34456bbe150b8ed6ce6f68403
'}]
commit_message:
Remove insecure default for signing_dir option.

The sample api-paste.ini file included an insecure value for the
signing_dir option for the keystone authtoken middleware.  Comment out
the option so that we just rely on the default behavior by default.

Fix bug 1174608.

Change-Id: I6189788953d789c34456bbe150b8ed6ce6f68403

commit_message:
Remove insecure default for signing_dir option.

The sample api-paste.ini file included an insecure value for the
signing_dir option for the keystone authtoken middleware.  Comment out
the option so that we just rely on the default behavior by default.

Fix bug 1174608.

Conflicts:
	etc/nova/api-paste.ini

Change-Id: I6189788953d789c34456bbe150b8ed6ce6f68403
(cherry picked from commit 58d6879b1caaa750c39c8e452a0634c24ffef2ce)

commit_message:
Copy the RHEL6 eventlet workaround from Oslo

Tests in oslo-incubator now need the horrendous hack to workaround an
issue with eventlet on RHEL6. We've moved the patch_tox_venv tool
and redhat-eventlet.patch into oslo-incubator, so add them to
openstack-common.conf.

Change-Id: I1acfec282b64d7582144b155119bedb1741db2f7

commit_message:
Fix test_mismatched_X test data deletion check

The assertion checking if data for an image is deleted correctly will
always pass. This is because it was using only the name of the file instead of
the absolute path.

Fixes bug 1177818

Change-Id: I8b99a4156ce72cb278c9c173a27253ab191dd451

Avoid extra queries when retrieving routers

fixes bug 1160333

Instead of making N additional sql requests,
use relationship and joined query.

commit_message:
Enable using multiple API versions for Identity Service.

Introduces a mechanism for switching between API versions,
and implements it in a proof-of-concept fashion for the
Keystone v3 API. Converts the existing Users and Projects
API methods to use it.

This changed some method signatures, and therefore altered
a number of views and tests. However, all code related to
the version cahnges is contained in the api.keystone module.
This seems like a sane process going forwards.

Future TODOs are marked in the code, including auto-detection
of API versions and better endpoint URL construction.

Partially implements blueprint api-capability-detection

Change-Id: Ied04200fe6c257aac2241d36628965a3bb6658b9

'}, {'account_id': 1207, 'date': '2013-05-08 14:38:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Many backends that do COW snapshots are going to have issues with this approach, and no use-case is provided in the bug. Without a clear reason to support this functionality, it is a great deal of added complexity with no clear gain."}, {'account_id': 2861, 'date': '2013-05-08 14:47:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Hi Duncan, the operation people in my company actually asked for this functionality. They wanted to put the snapshots in a different machines from where the volumes are located and they planned to specify the zone or host where to snapshot the volumes for their management.'}, {'account_id': 1207, 'date': '2013-05-08 14:56:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

I'll bring it up in the meeting today, but I'm not convinced snapshots are the right tool for this. Backups were added to provide true offline storage of data.

Would clone + migrate match your use-case? For any driver that does snapshots in a lightweight manner you're wanting to add a lot of complication.

What is the use-case? As in, what are they trying to achieve? Moving a volume between AZs I think is more of a migrate task than a snapshot case, and I'm reluctant to alter the already fuzzy semantics of snapshots further"}, {'account_id': 2861, 'date': '2013-05-08 15:11:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

The purpose is to prevent the loss of both the volume and the snapshot on the same machine, so snapshoting the volume in a different host or AZ is suggested by them.

I think clone plus migration can resolve the issue. Do you think it is possible to directly snapshot on a different machine, where the volume is located? For example, with a single command?'}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2013-05-08 15:29:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Personally I would solve this via backups (ie focus on finishing up/enhancing the backup service to do block to block backup).

This goes back to my whole rant on what's a snapshot, what's a backup etc.  Snapshots IMO are not DR backups obviously.  If you want disaster recovery or availability across zones that's why we implemented backups in Cinder."}, {'account_id': 1207, 'date': '2013-05-08 15:29:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

The backups to swift extension is the closest we have to a durable snapshot. Can you take a look at that and see if it meets your needs? The cinder snapshots is becoming a way of doing lightweight snapshots and I think there is benefit in keeping it that way'}, {'account_id': 2861, 'date': '2013-05-08 17:30:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Allow the user to snapshot a volume in a specified availability zone.

Fixed Bug1148597. This patch depends on the volume migration.

Change-Id: Ibeb80dee4357cce7b7b2e0381ae8e296f7358b54

for each driver.   The original bug was filed against LeftHand
and 3PAR, but several drivers exhibited a fixed backend name.

       bug #1172286

Change-Id: I4197f99bebd6ca8e4969795ae6edb537bc066c90

commit_message:
Fix ability to add custom volume_backend_name

This patch fixes the ability to set the volume_backend_name
for each driver.   The original bug was filed against LeftHand
and 3PAR, but several drivers exhibited a fixed backend name.

Fixes: bug #1175222
       bug #1172286

Change-Id: I4197f99bebd6ca8e4969795ae6edb537bc066c90
(cherry picked from commit 54a2ee48a4dc31cbf116b1e9d5add37efe66bc20)

commit_message:
Add db client packages to dev env setup doc.

Dev env setup doc hasn't been updated in a while and
needed the addition of the mysql and psql packages.

Tested this on a clean install and it looks like
the addition of these two pkgs should get us up to
date.

Change-Id: I66011478064bd8fb85bfaf56e8b14232226e0efc

commit_message:
Rename nova.compute.instance_types to flavors

First step in removing references to instance_types. Rename instnace_types.py
and update references to it. We currently use instance_type and flavor as
synonyms, to reduce confusion we are picking one. We are going with our own
terminology, flavors.

renamed:    nova/compute/instance_types.py -> nova/compute/flavors.py

Partially implements bp flavor-instance-type-dedup

Change-Id: I9dc04cf311aa8813be4f5329f23729d2c43cae6d

commit_message:
Enable swift

- Install swift as part of reddwarf-integration
- Add a swiftclient dependency to install the latest swiftclient as
  part of the guest image.

Fixes bug: 1171595

Change-Id: I9010bfb87ff5c3b113887ab63d09d6cd285e9975

commit_message:
Fix GroupSet assignment to use resource id instead of name

This allows the security groups to be passed to Quantum in the
expected format.

Change-Id: I7925bfdb71a076b4a2ecdeee396abf42d111ef8c
Fixes: bug #1164913

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-08 15:18:27.000000000', 'message': 'Import recent rootwrap features in local rootwrap

Import features developed in oslo-rootwrap during the Grizzly cycle (and
recently in havana) into quantum-rootwrap. This is the first step toward
using the common oslo-rootwrap into Quantum: the goal being to make both
implementations converge, we should avoid making local changes (and push
any required change into oslo-rootwrap instead from now on).

New features include:
- Optional logging (use_syslog)
- Searching for executables in a specified binary path (exec_dirs)
- New path-based PathFilter

Those features required a refactoring in the way executables are matched
and in configuration loading.

Implements bp quantum-rootwrap-new-features

Change-Id: Ia6a2e91c297ade471448dae0964adfd001a46086
'}, {'created': '2013-05-08 15:18:27.000000000', 'message': 'Import recent rootwrap features in local rootwrap

using the common oslo-rootwrap into Quantum: the goal being to make both
implementations converge, we should avoid making local changes (and push
any required change into oslo-rootwrap instead from now on).

New features include:
- Optional logging (use_syslog)
- Searching for executables in a specified binary path (exec_dirs)
- New path-based PathFilter

Those features required a refactoring in the way executables are matched
and in configuration loading.

Implements bp quantum-rootwrap-new-features

Change-Id: Ia6a2e91c297ade471448dae0964adfd001a46086

commit_message:
Import recent rootwrap features in local rootwrap

Import features developed in oslo-rootwrap during the Grizzly cycle (and
recently in havana) into quantum-rootwrap. This is the first step toward
using the common oslo-rootwrap into Quantum: the goal being to make both
implementations converge, we should avoid making local changes (and push
any required change into oslo-rootwrap instead from now on).

New features include:
- Optional logging (use_syslog)
- Searching for executables in a specified binary path (exec_dirs)
- New path-based PathFilter

Those features required a refactoring in the way executables are matched
and in configuration loading.

Implements bp quantum-rootwrap-new-features

Change-Id: Ia6a2e91c297ade471448dae0964adfd001a46086

commit_message:
Explicitely register options to fix intermittent failure

Using parallel tests, stackServiceTest sometimes fail with a
NoSuchOptError. Adding a register_engine_opts call seems to fix it.

Change-Id: I2bc6e7ab8d2e2cb20d1f3e7d0d93d75bdb631af3

zone of a set of instances. And add some tests for the filter.

commit_message:
Add affinity availability zone scheduler filter

Create an new filter to schedule the instance on a same/different availability
zone of a set of instances. And add some tests for the filter.

Since get instance availability zone code is need by many modules, so move it
into utils module nova.avalability_zones. And add some tests for the new
method.

Implemented bp: different-availability-zone-filter

Change-Id: Icee1db0db383a45bfec95209965725e522e90679

Hi Russel! Actually VolumeController in Nova already duplicates Cinder API and frankly I don't know the exact reason for such duplication. I just saw a confirmed bug in Nova and decided to fix it. I hope Chuck can clarify the reasoning a bit more :)"}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-05-08 02:06:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I think it's historical ... from before cinder was split out into its own project."}, {'account_id': 5948, 'date': '2013-05-08 06:43:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Add an ability to add/update/delete individual metadata key for volume

- implemented corresponding methods in volume.cinder.API
- added API controller for volume metadata

Fixes bug 1095271

Change-Id: I357616af5a8e53d6c2a2e3ab0f8ec75d8dad7920

commit_message:
Skip more tests that require Cinder backups

Most of the unit tests that require the backups feature in
python-cinderclient have been made optional, but a couple remained. This
patch makes those also conditional on the feature being available.

Change-Id: I8c954e7d7aa4b516b302140bfe5e66a7066717ed

commit_message:
templates : remove in-tree templates

Now we have the heat-templates repository, and the test dependencies
on the in-tree templates has been removed, we can remove these

Sure, it's really good to have lack of resource checking but likely we need to create the new bug for this."}, {'account_id': 6786, 'date': '2013-05-07 08:28:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I think that we should update bug description at maximum. The main point of the bug is that cluster remains in Active status in case of exceptions while launching vms. commit_message:
tests : convert test_template_format to test-local templates

test_template_format is different from all other tests, in that
we don't want to use the most minimal template possible, we
actually want to test conversion works with maximal/non-trivial
templates, so copy the two templates used by this test into a
local tests/templates directory, with a README caution that
in general inline-minimal templates are preferred.

Change-Id: Ib5421545103728385992625884f86f2667ee2465

commit_message:
Expanding the case of InstanceNotFound exception in get-vnc-console.

Up until now, asking for vnc console of an instance in ERROR status
would lead to InstanceNotReady exception which gets the driver's
instance name as a parameter, however, KeyError would be thrown
because this name is None. This case now will be part of the
InstanceNotFound exception.

Fixes bug 1175776

Change-Id: Id08707e6700fa684ad90af5b792e1397e2047203

subject: Avoid using nosetests --tests config option
messages:
[{'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-05-08 08:42:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Abandoned

I just wanted to put this up here to illustrate what we'd need to avoid the behavioural change in If4125d6bcbde63df95de129ac5c83b4a6d6f130a

I suspect Monty will hate this, and he's probably right"}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-08 08:40:47.000000000', 'message': "Avoid using nosetests --tests config option

Previously, it was possible to do:

  $> tox -- glance.tests.foo glance.tests.bar

but since we started using tests=glance/tests in setup.cfg[1] you must
now do this:

  $> tox -- --tests glance.tests.foo,glance.tests.bar

because positional args are appended to the value of --tests in the
config file, so you must override it with --tests on the command line.

Use nose's runmodule() API which allows us to set defaultTest to
glance/tests - this acts as a default value where no positional args
are supplied and restores the original behaviour.

[1]- to avoid having nose load code outside glance/tests and fail
because the _() builtin isn't installed

Change-Id: I6c701b09bf02d22c9dfac4a27ebe15c8d5ab631c
"}]
commit_message:
Avoid using nosetests --tests config option

Previously, it was possible to do:

  $> tox -- glance.tests.foo glance.tests.bar

but since we started using tests=glance/tests in setup.cfg[1] you must
now do this:

  $> tox -- --tests glance.tests.foo,glance.tests.bar

because positional args are appended to the value of --tests in the
config file, so you must override it with --tests on the command line.

Use nose's runmodule() API which allows us to set defaultTest to
glance/tests - this acts as a default value where no positional args
are supplied and restores the original behaviour.

[1]- to avoid having nose load code outside glance/tests and fail
because the _() builtin isn't installed

Change-Id: I6c701b09bf02d22c9dfac4a27ebe15c8d5ab631c

commit_message:
Use latest boto to address bugs in distro version.

Ubuntu's boto is fairly old, and affected by http://pad.lv/1177576. This
prevents cloud-init from working with OpenStack's ec2 metadata server
properly.

Change-Id: I110af27d7da520a53d55db3e04dc3382e7e17b38

Upstream cloud images likely have console=ttyS0 embedded in the kernel
commandline portion of the GRUB config. This makes local, direct testing

"}]
commit_message:
Add element to remove serial console.

Upstream cloud images likely have console=ttyS0 embedded in the kernel
commandline portion of the GRUB config. This makes local, direct testing
of the images substantially more difficult because upstart is writing
its output to a console that isn't being monitored.
This element simply removes console=ttyS0 from the grub configuration.

Change-Id: I07429bb504b467634071cc31ef184af730bbb5d6

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-08 08:02:16.000000000', 'message': 'Target ec2-user workaround to Ubuntu 12.10.

Ubuntu 13.04 has been confirmed to work properly, so only Ubuntu 12.10
is affected by the bug (http://pad.lv/1100920). Thus, we can narrow the
scope of the workaround to just "Ubuntu quantal".

Change-Id: Ib42e2bce2f4d0d2cfd6bdeb70cfa4162c2cd6433
'}]
commit_message:
Target ec2-user workaround to Ubuntu 12.10.

Ubuntu 13.04 has been confirmed to work properly, so only Ubuntu 12.10
is affected by the bug (http://pad.lv/1100920). Thus, we can narrow the
scope of the workaround to just "Ubuntu quantal".

Change-Id: Ib42e2bce2f4d0d2cfd6bdeb70cfa4162c2cd6433

commit_message:
Add libz-dev to os-svc-install to fix raring.

Before Ubuntu 13.04 libz-dev was pulled in as a dependency of the other
libraries mentioned here, but 13.04 changed the graph. Lxml and possibly
other modules link against libz during the pip install phase.

Change-Id: I201f7dd2fc40d36e5e0b193d51cfee200f946d17

commit_message:
Remove tripleo PPA from base element.

The PPA would have to be updated for each release we want to build for,
including raring. The PPA also gives the tripleo team root on every
built image, something we don't necessarily want.

A shallow review of the packages in the PPA and known elements shows
only one dependency in the tripleo-image-elements heat-cfntools element.

Change-Id: Ic514f929eba26014dd3a0d76d5bb3b8e9e0caf3c

"}, {'account_id': 1011, 'date': '2013-04-25 21:40:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

This patch is awesome, it addresses the problem reported in bug 1130676 properly in a very simple way.

Few similar issues exists in following methods:
1. update_user_project
2. delete_domain
3. delete_project
4. delete_user

I think pulling code out of the controller layer into the underlying driver that modifies data is tough for above methods. It may impact the driver interface too.

Any suggestions how to overcome these issues?'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2013-04-25 21:46:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I believe a similar strategy can be used for those other calls, Tushar. I just need to figure out why on Earth authentication is failing for the Tempest devstack run! :)

Adam is going to help take a look at it. I get all passing unit tests locally but not really sure what is going on with the calls in the devstack-gate setup. I have a feeling it has something to do with the way that "admin users" are handles specially with the "admin token", but I'm still investigating.

-jay'}, {'account_id': 6486, 'date': '2013-04-25 23:00:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(6 inline comments)

there should be a test case that shows that the operation is now atomic."}, {'account_id': 6124, 'date': '2013-04-26 10:02:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Jay, I did some analysis on the changes required in update_user_project API.

It seems difficult to move controller calls in update_user() which is called from this api, especially _delete_tokens_for_user() which uses token_api and a different sql backend driver.

I can see that there could be a lot of refactoring to do. Same goes for controller calls in api like 
delete_domain, delete_project, delete_user which need to be atomic.
It would be good if we can have a solution for this.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2013-04-26 16:15:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@Brant: thx for the feedback, I will make those fixes shortly.

@Rohan: So, I understand your concerns about some of those API calls, I do. I think I can solve for those situations, though, with a little bit of work without too much bother.'}, {'account_id': 6124, 'date': '2013-04-30 07:32:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@Jay, i tried this patchset 2, it seems the main issue is still unsolved, by default keystone will give you different sqlalchemy session for each get_session call,
hence it is unable to add a non existent (not commited, but flushed) user to the default project because create_user and add_user_to_project will get different session objects. This issue is solved by allowing only one session object per greenthread , check this out https://review.openstack.org/#/c/25517/5/keystone/common/sql/core.py

Create user failed logs:
http://paste.openstack.org/show/36698/'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-08 06:03:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-08 06:03:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

[{'created': '2013-04-25 18:16:28.000000000', 'message': 'Example alternate fix for atomic transactions

This patch shows an alternate way of fixing the atomic
identity modifications to allow drivers that are capable
of transactions to implement them as needed.

Basically, this required pulling code calls out of the
controller layer and into the underlying drivers. The
pattern to follow to allow transactional drivers to issue
appropriate session handling is to ensure each main
"entry point" on the controller only issues calls to the
drivers that return information (for instance, to check
if something exists when trying to delete or add) and
only a single driver call that modifies data. Let the drivers
themselves call other driver methods if need be, ensuring
that outer transactions can be contained, if the driver
supports it.

This patch just shows the create_user() example. Clearly
each controller method would need to be examined to ensure
only a single data-modifying call is made in any of the
controller methods.

Change-Id: I8631a99c5e6936d9902f28f3c38e593d245dcbd5
'}, {'created': '2013-04-25 20:44:19.000000000', 'message': 'Example alternate fix for atomic transactions

if something exists when trying to delete or add) and
only a single driver call that modifies data. Let the drivers
themselves call other driver methods if need be, ensuring
that outer transactions can be contained, if the driver

This patch just shows the create_user() example. Clearly
each controller method would need to be examined to ensure
only a single data-modifying call is made in any of the

Partially fixes lp 1130676

Change-Id: I8631a99c5e6936d9902f28f3c38e593d245dcbd5
'}]
commit_message:
Example alternate fix for atomic transactions

This patch shows an alternate way of fixing the atomic
identity modifications to allow drivers that are capable
of transactions to implement them as needed.

Basically, this required pulling code calls out of the
controller layer and into the underlying drivers. The
pattern to follow to allow transactional drivers to issue
appropriate session handling is to ensure each main
"entry point" on the controller only issues calls to the
drivers that return information (for instance, to check
if something exists when trying to delete or add) and
only a single driver call that modifies data. Let the drivers
themselves call other driver methods if need be, ensuring
that outer transactions can be contained, if the driver
supports it.

This patch just shows the create_user() example. Clearly
each controller method would need to be examined to ensure
only a single data-modifying call is made in any of the
controller methods.

Partially fixes lp 1130676

Change-Id: I8631a99c5e6936d9902f28f3c38e593d245dcbd5

Just so I understand, this simply rebuilds all the instances on the 'downed' host from the image originally used to create each instance?

Also, the response values are not likely to be very useful.  A 'success' value just means that the request to rebuild was submitted, not that it actually succeeded.  You might consider just returning a 202 response if the request to rebuild each instance was successfully submitted to the target compute or cell service."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-04-01 16:18:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Would it be easy to allow normal scheduling when no destination host is chosen? Unless the operator keeps a spare host for such situation, it's not unlikely that other compute nodes are already close to full and no single node can take all the new load."}, {'account_id': 7094, 'date': '2013-04-05 04:51:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

@Stanislaw Pitucha: There is already a blueprint(https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/find-host-and-evacuate-instance) that talks about making the host parameter for the server.evacuate optional. Once that is merged, we can make similar changes to host.evacuate to make host parameter optional, so it goes through the scheduler to find a host per instance. Will add another blueprint to make the changes.'}, {'account_id': 1528, 'date': '2013-04-05 07:30:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

@aarti perfect. thanks for clarifying.'}, {'account_id': 1528, 'date': '2013-04-09 14:20:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2013-04-10 15:04:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

I see this uses evacuate which rebuilds the instance.

Is the idea being that since the host has failed that the data for the instances (assuming it's not on shared storage) is unavailable now?

I'm having trouble understanding the usefulness of still having my instance running but losing all of my data and getting a new root password set that I can't access (as a user)."}, {'account_id': 2537, 'date': '2013-04-10 15:19:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(6 inline comments)

Some additional inline comments."}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2013-04-10 15:23:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I'm getting hung up on this as a PUT action...The URI here identifies the host to evacuate all the instances to, right?

RFC 2616, Section 9.6:

"The fundamental difference between the POST and PUT requests is reflected in the different meaning of the Request-URI. The URI in a POST request identifies the resource that will handle the enclosed entity. That resource might be a data-accepting process, a gateway to some other protocol, or a separate entity that accepts annotations. In contrast, the URI in a PUT request identifies the entity enclosed with the request -- the user agent knows what URI is intended and the server MUST NOT attempt to apply the request to some other resource. If the server desires that the request be applied to a different URI,"'}, {'account_id': 7005, 'date': '2013-04-10 15:31:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

@Johannes Erdfelt: I find great usefulness in this behavior. End-users often want to retain their IP even if they have to rebuild the instance from scratch in the event of data loss. More often, they will rebuild from a recent image that they have stored. 
As operators, we focus on getting the instance up and functioning, even if it is rebuilt from a base image, so that the end-user has the choice of how to proceed.  
We normally handle sending the new root password to the end-user out of band as part of our normal communications in the event of a host failure where we would be using this action. I agree that absent this, the end-user will not be aware of the new password, although they can always use an api call to reset it to a known value.'}, {'account_id': 7094, 'date': '2013-04-10 15:43:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: (8 inline comments)

@Johannes Erdfelt:
This functionality was requested by the admins. But I'm guessing a running instance is better than no instance at all, and for billing purposes too. This is the worse case, where the host data is completely irrecoverable.
The password is just returned to keep it consistent with the server evacuate response. Replies inline for other qns
@Nikhil : Replies inline
@Brian : Will make it a POST"}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2013-04-10 16:02:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: (2 inline comments)

I'm still dubious of how useful this is. Keeping the IP address isn't useful if I can't keep the data."}, {'account_id': 7005, 'date': '2013-04-10 17:29:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

Most of our end-users seem to disagree with that sentiment. They care more about keeping the IP than the data on the instance, especially if they have images or a file-based backup solution in place that will let them restore data on their own. From my point of view as an operator, I prefer to let the customer have the choice to delete the instance if they have no use for it now or keep it around if they do. This is preferable to our making the decision for them that they lose the instance and IP in the event of data loss due to a host failure.

At a specific to us level, we sometimes set expectations that we will have the instance available within x timeframe, even if it is rebuilt from a base image. Therefore, this behavior has become necessary to us due to business logic. I know this won't apply to everyone, but it is a constraint that we operate under.

From a bigger picture view, this is about being able to have a single call to handle all the instances on a downed host. There are times when we can later recover data for some, but not all, of the instances. By rebuilding them all first, we have somewhere to attach the recovered data, and they retain their IP and everything. Determination can then be made, in concert with the end-user, regarding the fate of the instances that we could not recover data for."}, {'account_id': 2537, 'date': '2013-04-10 17:39:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: (2 inline comments)

Reply inline.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2013-04-10 18:20:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

Here's my problem with this behavior, you're making a decision for the user that may not be applicable to all users.

I can (somewhat) appreciate the desire to keep the IP address, but rebuilding the instance I think is a mistake.

For instance, if I have built an instance off a snapshot and it gets rebuilt and starts serving *old* data, that's horrible. Especially if I have to wait to be contacted by someone to get the new root password.

You're making a decision to make some users happy at the expense of making other users unhappy. You're always going to make the wrong decision at some point.

Why can't this be user initiated? Put the instance into some sort of down or failed state and let the user rebuild the instance onto a new host instead? Or they could just delete if they don't care about the IP anymore.

It will be more work, but I'd argue that if we can't make the right decision for the user, then let the user make the decision for themselves."}, {'account_id': 7005, 'date': '2013-04-10 19:31:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

"Here's my problem with this behavior, you're making a decision for the user that may not be applicable to all users."

This is true any time you make a decision that affects more than one user. But the decision not to rebuild is also a decision for the user that may not be applicable to all users. From our experience, the majority of our users will fall into the category of wanting their instance rebuilt. Additionally, we have legal requirements that state we must rebuild all instances in the event of data loss within a specific time frame. This is specific to us, but it means that this decision is hard coded into our business logic at this time.

Additionally, the users that won't care about keeping the IP address are usually those who have built redundancy into their application design from the start. They won't be bothered by losing one node, and can just spin a new one up to replace it. They are also the users most likely to notice and take corrective action themselves, and to have app logic to prevent the node from rejoining and serving up old content. In many of these cases, the instance doesn't hold the data itself, but is pulling from a database or other content source, and will have a configuration management solution in place that will handle getting it back up to date.

Rebuilding will make more users happy, and the ones who don't want it rebuilt are the users most likely to a) not be impacted by the loss of one instance and b) have mechanisms in place to prevent against issues caused by it being rebuilt.

"I can (somewhat) appreciate the desire to keep the IP address, but rebuilding the instance I think is a mistake.
For instance, if I have built an instance off a snapshot and it gets rebuilt and starts serving *old* data, that's horrible. Especially if I have to wait to be contacted by someone to get the new root password."

You don't have to wait to be contacted with the root password. You can always reset the password from the API at any time. You will have been notified that your instance is down, so you will have an opportunity to remove it from a load balancer or anything else you need to do to prevent it from serving content when it comes online if your app doesn't handle this for you already.

We don't work through a hardware failure without engaging the end users while the issue is still ongoing. We also frequently rebuild from a base image, and then manually migrate over the customer's data to replace the new disk containers. This requires us to start by rebuilding from the base image.

"You're making a decision to make some users happy at the expense of making other users unhappy. You're always going to make the wrong decision at some point."

Again, not rebuilding is also a decision. You are basically arguing that we should be handling each instance on a case-by-case basis, waiting for customer input about what action they want us to take. We have legal requirements that tell us what actions we must take. We also have issues of scale, which is why we need this action in the first place. We handle too many server failures on a regular basis to have to touch each instance individually every time. 

Not rebuilding will make happy the customers who don't care, and cause problems and extended downtime for the majority of end users who do care, in addition to breaking our contracts with our end users.

"Why can't this be user initiated? Put the instance into some sort of down or failed state and let the user rebuild the instance onto a new host instead? Or they could just delete if they don't care about the IP anymore.
It will be more work, but I'd argue that if we can't make the right decision for the user, then let the user make the decision for themselves."

I wouldn't be opposed to a customer facing method for initiating a rebuild in the event of a downed host, but it does not replace the need for this action for admins. 

We have a requirement to restore an instance to an operational state, even if it is rebuilt from a base image, within a given time frame. We cannot wait for a customer that we have trouble contacting to make a decision about how they want their instance handled. Especially not when we are trying to move off of failing hardware, and time is of the essence.

If the customer wants their instance deleted instead of rebuilt, and they contact us after being informed that the hardware has failed, that is trivial for us to handle. If they wanted it rebuilt and we waited until they told us that, they will usually be very upset.

Ultimately, nobody is forcing you to use this action. It simply takes an existing action (evacuate an instance) and wraps it so that it applies to all instances on a given host. If you make the decision as an operator of your cloud that you should not rebuild from base images in the event of data loss, then you don't call this action, or even allow it in your policy. You've made your decision, and the code isn't forcing it upon you. However, this is a behavior that we use extensively, and we need the code to support this capability.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2013-04-10 20:19:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

Not rebuilding is not a decision you force on the user. You didn't decide to make the hardware fail, you're just leaving down as down.

Ultimately, you're trying to push your business logic or policy into core code. This isn't the right place for that.

If you want to implement some sort of business logic of policy outside of nova, then that's fine. This patch should only be the logic necessary to implement that.

In fact, it looks like everything you need already exists in the evacuate extension with all of your business logic and policy implemented using that API.

Why does this even need to be an extension? It's something that could easily be implemented without being an extension."}, {'account_id': 2667, 'date': '2013-04-17 04:48:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

See a comment inline."}, {'account_id': 7094, 'date': '2013-04-17 05:19:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: (1 inline comment)

@Alex Glikson	: Reply inline'}, {'account_id': 2667, 'date': '2013-04-17 05:31:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: (1 inline comment)

inline'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2013-04-22 16:26:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

I think this kind of thing should be handled in python-novaclient, and/or provider specific scripts.

Starting a thread on the email list for this one."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-04-29 12:34:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Do not merge

Consensus on the thread seems to be that this should be outside of nova.'}, {'account_id': 6828, 'date': '2013-04-30 07:48:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

For the records: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2013-April/007646.html'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-08 06:03:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-08 06:03:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Abandoned

commit_message:
Added a new evacuate action to os-hosts extension

This is a PUT action on the host that would evacuate all instances on
the host to the target host specifed in the params.
Also added separate entries to the policy.json for access control.
Moved helpers like '_delete_server' and '_wait_for_deletion' from
tests/integrated/test_servers.py to
tests/integrated/integrated_helpers.py

Implements: blueprint evacuate-host
Change-Id: I986b316e86c921c247335b253887eb1ae3594c4f

Hi Zhouyue,
As you mentioned in the mail list, it looks like you are also working on you project by using the tempest, so you input will be appreciated regarding this refactoring.'}, {'account_id': 4184, 'date': '2013-01-09 03:05:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

Thanks, Zhongyue!'}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2013-01-09 05:00:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: (4 inline comments)

Nice cleanup! Minor comments inline.

I was a bit concerned that each test was going to create its own server, but I realized that in the general case a tradeoff between memory usage and execution time will probably have to err on the side of execution.  In this case, there isn't a good reason to create a VM for each test, but it sets a good example for future efforts."}, {'account_id': 4184, 'date': '2013-01-09 22:40:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 4184, 'date': '2013-01-09 22:41:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 4184, 'date': '2013-01-09 23:13:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Hi Maru, I appreciated so much for your input.

As you mentioned the VM is created in every test case right now. we totally agree with you. we'd like to continue work on it if the community like this refactor. :-)
Currently what we can propose is creating the probe port instead of creating VM, but we need discuss with you guys,
also we need discuss how to proceed the next step as ZhongYue and others are also working on more quantum test cases.

Thanks again!

Best regards,

Jason"}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2013-01-10 00:24:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

'}, {'account_id': 4325, 'date': '2013-01-17 14:16:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

I fail to understand why the environment is not created in setupclass and then shared between the two tests."}, {'account_id': 4184, 'date': '2013-01-18 00:20:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Hi Jaroslav,

Thank you for you comment, what we are trying to do here is isolating the test environment in order to avoid the test cases effecting each other, so we create the clean environment every time other than using the same environment to test all the cases. 

Jason'}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-01-18 06:33:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

Long time ago I considered using contextmanager, but  I had several concerns with them.

- IMHO test_* logic should be as flat as possible
- In complex test cases when you need to allocate a resource , do something else, then you need to do another allocation, .... and so and so on
 You will have lot of embedded "with" contexts, and the pep8 limits us to 80 character per line.

Probably you seen it when you created the "basic_scenario".

- This solution makes very difficult the parallel resource deallocation, with volume, snapshot, server, image .. , where you can issue the "delete" to all resource in one step, and wait on all termination in another step.


(The gate VM's has limited CPU resources, so I even wouldn't repeat the keypair creation per user.)

Please try to use the setUpClass/tearDownClass as other test does for common/shared resource allocation/deallocation.

IMHO We don't want to use a different hammer for every classes, because it makes more difficult the global refactoring attempts.'}, {'account_id': 4325, 'date': '2013-01-18 08:55:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

If you want to have the tests isolated, you can use setUp/tearDown/addCleanup.'}, {'account_id': 4184, 'date': '2013-01-19 02:47:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (1 inline comment)

Hi afazekas,

Thank you for your input, we appreciate so much.

Regarding the keypair absolutely we can put it into superclass.

Regarding the VM created at each test case, we can using the quantum debug probe port instead of launching the VM, so we do not need to create the server at each test cases anymore. 

Since purpose of this patch is refactoring, we did not want to go too far at this time so we did not introduce it in.

Best regards,

Jason'}, {'account_id': 4184, 'date': '2013-01-19 02:51:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (1 inline comment)

commit_message:
Refactoring the quantum basic test case.

The implementation creates the basic network
scenario by using python "with" statement,
so the following test cases can execute relative
testing against it.

There are more quantum test cases will be
developed and pushed to community based on the
same solution.

Change-Id: I024509fd67239fec791d6cec69cd8c919b88a61c

"}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2013-04-22 21:32:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

What will use this besides cinder?'}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2013-04-22 21:38:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The idea was that Nova would likely use this as well, and ultimately may use this work (the LVM or the upcoming raw_disk pieces) to do things with ephemeral/instance locations.

This opens up some possibilities for things like efficient image management and storage.

Ultimately I see the ability to do things like import these volumes/disks into Cinder as well and assign iscsi-targets etc.'}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2013-04-22 21:42:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Something else along these lines that folks have mentioned is to run a cinder-volume service on each node that includes local semantics, and to add better features to the nova/volume/cinder API to roll some of this functionality up into nova (ie "nova boot" that creates a volume on the fly for you if requested, rather than requiring the seperate 'cinder create').

With the scheduler additions this is something that I think we could now do efficiently and include things like specifying local to compute node etc.

Just more food for thought...'}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2013-04-23 00:14:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2013-04-23 00:15:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Work In Progress'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-04-23 00:17:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/27289/2/check/gate-oslo-incubator-python26/1420 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/27289/2/check/gate-oslo-incubator-python26-rhel6/109 : SUCCESS (non-voting)
- http://logs.openstack.org/27289/2/check/gate-oslo-incubator-python27/1422 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2013-04-23 01:02:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

OK, thanks for the details. It still feels a little odd to have something so domain-specific in the common library, but if it makes it easier to share features between nova and cinder than I guess that's a win. :-)"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-04-23 16:26:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Cool stuff John

Maybe this should be a two step thing - refactor Cinders code, keeping the code in Cinder. Then once you (or someone else) has the bandwidth to make Nova use it, move it to Oslo

If the code is only used by a single service, then moving it to Oslo just adds development overhead. And there's very little past evidence that services will adopt an Oslo API of their own accord :)

i.e. let's not add this to Oslo until we're ready (with a patch) to make Nova use it"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-08 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button  under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-08 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button  under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

driver in Cinder (turns the driver into an interface calling
this lib), as well as the ability to use raw/non-lvm local
disks.

Future changes should like send things like attach code and iscsi
connect upstream to common as well as there's numerous places where

Change-Id: Iee40a9c9290d3b3e51be1622df5d19e395099601

commit_message:
Add common block storage library to OSLO.

Add ability to perform operations on local LVM and Disk
resources via OSLO block_storage library.  This will
start with the necessary components to replace the LVM.py
driver in Cinder (turns the driver into an interface calling
this lib).

Raw disks would be a seperate patch.

Future changes should like send things like attach code and iscsi
connect upstream to common as well as there's numerous places where
we're currently duplicating this code across projects.

Partial implementation of blueprint: shared-block-storage-library

Change-Id: Iee40a9c9290d3b3e51be1622df5d19e395099601

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-02 09:04:59.000000000', 'message': 'Copy Nova's workaround for RHEL6 eventlet issue

The eventlet on PyPI basically doesn't work on RHEL because we (Red Hat)
screwed up by not taking monkey patching into account when backporting
an API from python 3. This is the series of events:

  1) We backported a patch to RHEL6 from Python 3 which added an
     optional 'timeout' argument to subprocess.Popen:

       http://pkgs.devel.redhat.com/cgit/rpms/python/commit/?h=rhel-6.3&id=fc9a3f0e07

     This might sound innocuous but it means the wait() function get
     called with a timeout argument

  2) eventlet overrides this function, but doesn't know about the
     timeout argument, so it fails. To reproduce, try applying this to
     your python 2.7:

       https://gist.github.com/markmc/5500967

  3) eventlet doesn't yet support Python 3, so the only time this issue
     crops up is if you use eventlet on RHEL6

  4) We've fixed eventlet in EPEL6, but the issue still remains if you
     install eventlet from upstream

  5) Dave Malcolm sent a pull request to eventlet, but it has stalled:

       https://bitbucket.org/eventlet/eventlet/pull-request/30/add-dummy-timeout-parameter-to

Nova has long had a nasty workaround to patch eventlet in our virtualenv
and we now need this workaround in oslo-incubator to test processutils.
Let's add it here and make nova sync it from oslo-incubator.

I really hope we can get eventlet upstream "fixed" and the fix released
soon. When that happens, we can kill all this nastiness.

Change-Id: I62ce43a330d7ae94eda4c7498782a655e63747fa
'}, {'created': '2013-05-02 09:23:25.000000000', 'message': 'Copy Nova's workaround for RHEL6 eventlet issue

commit_message:
Copy Nova's workaround for RHEL6 eventlet issue

The eventlet on PyPI basically doesn't work on RHEL because we (Red Hat)
screwed up by not taking monkey patching into account when backporting
an API from python 3. This is the series of events:

  1) We backported a patch to RHEL6 from Python 3 which added an
     optional 'timeout' argument to subprocess.Popen:

       http://pkgs.devel.redhat.com/cgit/rpms/python/commit/?h=rhel-6.3&id=fc9a3f0e07

     This might sound innocuous but it means the wait() function get
     called with a timeout argument

  2) eventlet overrides this function, but doesn't know about the
     timeout argument, so it fails. To reproduce, try applying this to
     your python 2.7:

       https://gist.github.com/markmc/5500967

  3) eventlet doesn't yet support Python 3, so the only time this issue
     crops up is if you use eventlet on RHEL6

  4) We've fixed eventlet in EPEL6, but the issue still remains if you
     install eventlet from upstream

  5) Dave Malcolm sent a pull request to eventlet, but it has stalled:

       https://bitbucket.org/eventlet/eventlet/pull-request/30/add-dummy-timeout-parameter-to

Nova has long had a nasty workaround to patch eventlet in our virtualenv
and we now need this workaround in oslo-incubator to test processutils.
Let's add it here and make nova sync it from oslo-incubator.

I really hope we can get eventlet upstream "fixed" and the fix released
soon. When that happens, we can kill all this nastiness.

Change-Id: I62ce43a330d7ae94eda4c7498782a655e63747fa

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-07 04:44:28.000000000', 'message': 'Standardize template instance types on nova defaults

Based on the following
$ nova flavor-list
+----+-----------+-----------+------+-----------+------+-------+
| ID | Name      | Memory_MB | Disk | Ephemeral | Swap | VCPUs |
+----+-----------+-----------+------+-----------+------+-------+
| 1  | m1.tiny   | 512       | 0    | 0         |      | 1
| 2  | m1.small  | 2048      | 20   | 0         |      | 1

- m1.small is specified as the Default for InstanceType parameters
  (previously this was m1.medium or m1.large. It would be better if
  there was a flavor with 1GB memory, but m1.small is the next most
  appropriate.)
- m1.tiny is the only flavor mapped to Arch=32 in AWSInstanceType2Arch
- AllowedValues and AWSInstanceType2Arch mapping is now limited to the
  following nova defaults:
  [ "m1.tiny", "m1.small", "m1.medium", "m1.large", "m1.xlarge" ]

This will allow heat/tools/nova_create_flavors.sh to be deleted.

Part of blueprint default-nova-flavors

Change-Id: Ia8bba4bd17a2d665676104fbdeb1e188b55aeeaf
'}]
commit_message:
Standardize template instance types on nova defaults

Based on the following
$ nova flavor-list
+----+-----------+-----------+------+-----------+------+-------+
| ID | Name      | Memory_MB | Disk | Ephemeral | Swap | VCPUs |
+----+-----------+-----------+------+-----------+------+-------+
| 1  | m1.tiny   | 512       | 0    | 0         |      | 1
| 2  | m1.small  | 2048      | 20   | 0         |      | 1

- m1.small is specified as the Default for InstanceType parameters
  (previously this was m1.medium or m1.large. It would be better if
  there was a flavor with 1GB memory, but m1.small is the next most
  appropriate.)
- m1.tiny is the only flavor mapped to Arch=32 in AWSInstanceType2Arch
- AllowedValues and AWSInstanceType2Arch mapping is now limited to the
  following nova defaults:
  [ "m1.tiny", "m1.small", "m1.medium", "m1.large", "m1.xlarge" ]

This will allow heat/tools/nova_create_flavors.sh to be deleted.

Part of blueprint default-nova-flavors

Change-Id: Ia8bba4bd17a2d665676104fbdeb1e188b55aeeaf

commit_message:
Run hooks even without cfn-init Metadata.

When we don't have AWS::CloudFormation::Init in Metadata, this just
means that cfn-init cannot do anything. However, cfn-hup still has hooks
which are just scheduled to be run on any change in the Metadata.

Fixes bug #1155999

Change-Id: I21c4f2137f8045128a86278b4d90768ea97455d1

commit_message:
Transition from openstack.common.setup to pbr.

Declarative approach to packaging, obviates the need for copying files.
Also, removes the need for setup.py to import files from the nova
module.

./run_tests.sh now ensure's that nova.egg-info/entry_points.txt is up to
date before running tests.

Change-Id: I7b7a18e065a62491ade54fbed5d8400db1d4e6c7

subject: libvirt: ignore NOSTATE in resume_state_on_host_boot() method.

Occasionally, libvirt would get NOSTATE from hypervisor as instance
state. Thus if we don't ignore instances in NOSTATE in
resume_state_on_host_boot() method, we would mistakenly reboot such
instances when we restart nova-compute service or on host boot. This
patch fixes this by adding NOSTATE into ignored_states.

Change-Id: I651cb043d7f97fde29b2a62e6ead8222062f01f7

commit_message:
libvirt: ignore NOSTATE in resume_state_on_host_boot() method.

Occasionally, libvirt would get NOSTATE from hypervisor as instance
state. Thus if we don't ignore instances in NOSTATE in
resume_state_on_host_boot() method, we would mistakenly reboot such
instances when we restart nova-compute service or on host boot. This
patch fixes this by adding NOSTATE into ignored_states.

Bug 1176897

Change-Id: I651cb043d7f97fde29b2a62e6ead8222062f01f7
